'''Ali Illahism''' ({{lang-fa|علی‌اللّهی}}) is a name attributed to a [[syncretic]] religion which has been practiced in parts of Iranian [[Luristan]] which combines elements of [[Shia Islam]] with older religions. It centers on the belief that there have been successive [[incarnations]] of the [[Deity]] throughout history, and Ali Ilahees reserve particular reverence for [[Ali]],<ref>{{cite book | last1=Woulfe Sheil | first1=Lady Mary Leonora | last2 = Sheil | first2 = Sir Justin | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=zYZi0qSfHxoC&pg=PA199#v=onepage&q&f=false | title = Glimpses of Life and Manners in Persia | year = 1856 | page = 199}}</ref> the son-in-law of the Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]], who is considered one such incarnation.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-SQe_sNtIaMC&pg=PA216&lpg=PA216&dq=ali+illahism&source=bl&ots=6aa4DgyQSn&sig=265ueJ-UCGd_z_P-QtRZ-VtWhUo&hl=en&ei=KlgXTb-QIsOu8QPOj4WEBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDEQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=ali%2520illahism&f=false|title=Discoveries in the Ruins of Nineveh and Babylon: With Travels in Armenia, Kurdistan and the Desert: Being the Result of a Second Expedition Undertaken for the Trustees of the British Museum|last=Layard|first=Austen Henry|date=2010-08-31|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781108016773|page=216|language=en}}</ref> Various [[rites]] have been attributed as Ali Ilahian, similarly to the [[Yezidis]], [[Alawi|Ansaris]], and all sects whose doctrine is unknown to the surrounding [[Muslim]] and [[Christian]] population. Observers have described it as an [[wikt:agglomeration|agglomeration]] of the customs and rites of several earlier religions, including [[Zoroastrianism]], historically because travelogues were "evident that there is no definite code which can be described as Ali Illahism".<ref>{{cite journal |title=To Mesopotamia and Kurdistan in disguise with historical notices of Kurdish tribes and the Chaldeans of Kurdistan. (Excerpt) |journal=International Journal of Kurdish Studies |date=2008 |last=Soane |first=Ely B. |page=10 |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-193095988.html |accessdate=2017-03-23 }}; {{cite book |last=Soane |first1=Ely B. |url=https://archive.org/details/tomesopotamiakur00soanuoft |format=PDF |title=To Mesopotamia and Kurdistan in disguise : with historical notices of the Kurdish tribes and the Chaldeans of Kurdistan |chapter=Of Kurds and their Country |location=Boston |publisher=Small, Maynard |year=1914 |page=384|ol=23348805M}}</ref>
Sometimes Ali-Illahism is used as a general term for the [[Ghulat|several denominations that venerate or deify Ali]], like the [[Kaysanites]], the [[Alawis]] or the [[Yarsanism|Ahl-e Haqq/Yarsanis]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.let.uu.nl/~Martin.vanBruinessen/personal/publications/Bruinessen_Religion_in_Kurdistan.pdf#page=9 |format=PDF |title=Religion in Kurdistan |last=Bruinessen |first=Martin van |work=Universiteit Utrecht |accessdate=2017-03-30|page=9}}</ref> others to mean the [[Ahl-e Haqq]].<ref>{{Cite book|first=Matti|last=Moosa|title=Extremist Shiites - The Ghulat Sects|publisher=Syracuse University Press|year=1987|page=185|chapter=16. The Ahl-i Haqq (Ali Ilahis) - Origins and Identity|chapterurl=https://books.google.pt/books?id=WYO1BqdvX9EC&pg=PA185|series=Contemporary issues in the Middle East|isbn =9780815624110}}</ref>
==In the ''Dabestan-e Mazaheb''== The ''[[Dabestan-e Mazaheb]]'' (a Persian book of the 17th century about the [[South Asian]] religions) presents the Ali Illahians as a sect that respected [[Muhammad]] and [[Ali]] and discarded the [[Quran]] as it was compiled under [[Umar]]. They avoided killing any animals and believed that the rules allowing the killing of some animals are created by [[Abu Bakr]], Umar, [[Uthman ibn Affan]] and their followers.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Dabistán, or School of Manners|chapter=An Account of the Ali Ilahían |chapter-url=http://persian.packhum.org/persian/pf?file=15501052&ct=34 |volume=II |date=1843 |accessdate=2017-03-23 |pages=451–460|translator-last1=Shea|translator-first1=David|translator-last2=Troyer|translator-first2=Anthony|url=http://persian.packhum.org/persian/pf?file=15501050&ct=0}}</ref>

{{slavery}} Bahá’u’lláh formally abolished the practice of slavery among Baha’is in the [[Kitab-i-Aqdas]] (ca. 1873). The English translation of the relevant section is as follows:
::''It is forbidden you to trade in slaves, be they men or women. It is not for him who is himself a servant to buy another of God's servants, and this hath been prohibited in His Holy Tablet. Thus, by His mercy, hath the commandment been recorded by the Pen of justice. Let no man exalt himself above another; all are but bondslaves before the Lord, and all exemplify the truth that there is none other God but Him. He, verily, is the All-Wise, Whose wisdom encompasseth all things.''
:::''Bahá’u’lláh, The Kitab-i-Aqdas, p. 45)''<ref>{{cite book |author = Bahá'u'lláh |authorlink = Bahá'u'lláh |year = 1873 |page = 45 |title = The Kitáb-i-Aqdas: The Most Holy Book |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-85398-999-0 |url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-5.html#pg45 }}</ref>
In his letter to Queen Victoria, written to her between 1868 and 1872, Bahá’u’lláh had singled out the action of the British government in using its power to stamp out the world trade in slaves for particular commendation.
::''We have been informed that thou hast forbidden the trading in slaves, both men and women. This, verily, is what God hath enjoined in this wondrous Revelation. God hath, truly, destined a reward for thee, because of this.
:::''(Bahá’u’lláh, The Proclamation of Bahá’u’lláh, p. 30)''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www-personal.umich.edu/~jrcole/bhkings.htm|title="Bahá'u'lláh's Tablets to the Rulers" by Juan R.I. Cole, Department of History, University of Michigan|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref>
In 1844, when the Báb declared his mission, slavery was still [[Slavery in Iran|very widespread]]. When the Báb went on the [[Hajj]] pilgrimage in 1844, he was accompanied by [[Quddús]] and an Ethiopian slave.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bahai.org/library/authoritative-texts/the-universal-house-of-justice/messages/19760926_001/19760926_001.pdf |title= Message to the International Teaching Conference, Nairobi, Kenya |last= Universal House of Justice | authorlink= Universal House of Justice |first= |date= September 26, 1976 |website= Selected Messages of the Universal House of Justice |publisher= |access-date= February 23, 2017 }}</ref> The family the Báb was born into possessed several slaves: one was his first tutor, and the subject of a eulogy penned by his young pupil/master in later years, crediting him as having raised him and praises him.<ref>{{cite journal | author1=Nader Saiedi |author2=Translated by Omid Ghaemmaghami | title =The Ethiopian King | journal =Baha’i Studies Review | volume =17 | issue = | pages =181–186 | date =2011 | language =English | url =http://bahaiteachings.org/a-slave-educates-a-prophet | doi =10.1386/bsr.17.181/7 | access-date = Sep 7, 2016}}</ref> The Báb was martyred in 1850, at which time he had not abrogated or changed the laws of Islam that permitted and regulated the practice. Slavery was not finally abolished in Iran until 1929.<ref group=note>On February 7, 1929 the Iranian National Parliament ratified an anti-slavery bill that outlawed slave trade or any other claim of ownership over human beings. The bill also empowered the government to take immediate action for emancipation of all slaves.</ref><ref> {{cite court |litigants =Law for prohibition of slave trade and liberation of slaves at the point of entry |vol =1 |reporter = Iranian National Parliament |opinion =7 |pinpoint = Page 156 |date =1929 |url= http://rc.majlis.ir/fa/law/show/91872}} </ref> For comparison though slavery had been abolished in the British Empire as late as 1833,<ref group=note>The [[Slavery Abolition Act 1833|Slavery Abolition Act]] passed in 1833 abolished slavery in the British Empire on 1 August 1834 (with the exception of [[St. Helena]], Ceylon and the territories administered by the East India Company, though these exclusions were later repealed). Under the Act, slaves were granted full [[emancipation]] after a period of 4 to 6 years of "apprenticeship".</ref> it remained legal in the United States until 1863.<ref group=note>On September 22, 1862, Lincoln issued a preliminary proclamation warning that he would order the emancipation of all slaves in any state in rebellion against the Union this took effect on January 1, 1863.</ref>
Nor was slavery immediately abolished among followers of the Báb and Bahá’u’lláh.
The household in which Bahá’u’lláh was raised also included a number of slaves. He became the owner of these on the death of his father, whereupon he gave each of them the choice of remaining in his service as free servants, or leaving.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://bahaiteachings.org/bahaullah-frees-the-slaves | title =Baha’u’llah Frees the Slaves | author-first= Christopher | author-last= Buck | date =January 13, 2014 | website =Bahaiteachings.org | access-date =Sep 7, 2016 }}</ref> saying "How, then, can this thrall claim for himself ownership of any other human being? Nay,…."<ref>{{cite web | url =http://bahaiteachings.org/liberating-every-slave | title =Liberating Every Slave | author-first= Christopher | author-last= Buck | date =September 24, 2014 | website =Bahaiteachings.org | access-date =Sep 7, 2016 }}</ref>
All of them chose to take up their freedom in full and leave his household, except one called Isfandíyár, who remained a loyal servant, and later a well known follower, of Bahá’u’lláh.<ref name=HouseResearch>{{cite web | url =http://bahai-library.com/uhj_servants_household_bahaullah | title =Servants in the Households of Baha'u'llah and the Bab |author=Universal House of Justice | date = Feb 2, 2000| website =Bahai-Library.com | publisher =Research Department of the Bahá'í World Center | access-date = Sep 21, 2016}}</ref>
==Partial list of slaves==
*Hájí Mubárak - purchased at the age of 5 years old by Hájí Mírzá Abú'l-Qásím, the great-grandfather of Shoghi Effendi and brother-in-law of the Báb, Hájí Mubárak was sold to the Báb in 1842 at the age of 19 for fourteen [[Iranian toman|tomans]].<ref name="Afnan 2009, p.5">{{Citation |first=Abul-Qasim |last=Afnan |year=1999 |title= Black Pearls: Servants in the Household of the Bab and Baha'u'llah |publisher= Kalimat Press |location = |page= 5| isbn=1-890688-03-7}}</ref> [[Nabíl-i-A`zam]] relates in ''[[The Dawn-Breakers]]'' that [[Mullá Husayn]], the first [[Letters of the Living|Letter of the Living]], was welcomed at the Báb's mansion by Hájí Mubárak.<ref name="Azam 1932, p.53">{{Citation |last=[[Nabíl-i-A`zam]] |year=1932| edition= 1997 | url= http://bahai-library.com/books/dawnbreakers/chapters/3.html#53 | title= Dawn-Breakers: Nabil's Narrative of the Early Days of the Baha'i Revelation |publisher= Bahá'í Publishing Trust |page= 53| isbn=978-0877430100}}</ref> Hájí Mubárak died at about the age of 40 and is buried in the grounds of the [[Imam Husayn Shrine]] in Karbala, Iraq.<ref name="Afnan 2009, p.18">{{Citation |first=Abul-Qasim |last=Afnan |year=1999 |title= Black Pearls: Servants in the Household of the Bab and Baha'u'llah |publisher= Kalimat Press |location = |page= 18| isbn=1-890688-03-7}}</ref> *Fiddih - acquired by the Báb when she was no older than 7 years of age, Fiddih served the Báb's wife [[Khadíjih-Bagum]].<ref name="Afnan 2009, p.21">{{Citation |first=Abul-Qasim |last=Afnan |year=1999 |title= Black Pearls: Servants in the Household of the Bab and Baha'u'llah |publisher= Kalimat Press |location = |page= 21| isbn=1-890688-03-7}}</ref><ref name="Munírih Khánum p.26">{{cite book |last=[[Munirih Khánum]] |date=1987 |title=Munirih Khánum: Memoirs and Letters |url=http://bahai-library.com/munirih_khanum_memoirs_letters |location= |publisher=Kalimat Press |pages=26–37 |isbn=978-0933770515}}</ref> Fiddih would die the same night as her master.<ref name="Afnan 2009, p.26">{{Citation |first=Abul-Qasim |last=Afnan |year=1999 |title= Black Pearls: Servants in the Household of the Bab and Baha'u'llah |publisher= Kalimat Press |location = |page= 26| isbn=1-890688-03-7}}</ref> *Isfandíyár - inherited by Bahá'u'lláh after the passing of his father, [[Mírzá Buzurg]], Isfandíyár was granted manumission but remained a servant in Bahá'u'lláh's house in Tehran,<ref name="Blomfield 1967, p.40">{{cite book |last=Blomfield |first=Sara Louisa Ryan | authorlink=Sara Blomfield |date=2007 |title=The Chosen Highway |url=http://bahai-library.com/blomfield_chosen_highway&chapter=2 |publisher=George Ronald Publisher |page=40 |isbn=978-0853985099}}</ref><ref name="Afnan 2009, p.27">{{Citation |first=Abul-Qasim |last=Afnan |year=1999 |title= Black Pearls: Servants in the Household of the Bab and Baha'u'llah |publisher= Kalimat Press |location = |page= 27| isbn=1-890688-03-7}}</ref> Isfandíyár died in Mazandaran <ref name="Afnan 2009, p.30">{{Citation |first=Abul-Qasim |last=Afnan |year=1999 |title= Black Pearls: Servants in the Household of the Bab and Baha'u'llah |publisher= Kalimat Press |location = |page= 30| isbn=1-890688-03-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=[['Abdu'l-Bahá]] |first= |date=1982 |title=Promulgation of Universal Peace: Talks Delivered by Abdu'l Baha during His Visit to the United States and Canada in 1912 |url=http://bahai-library.com/writings/abdulbaha/pup/26/sec-10.html |location= |publisher=Bahai Publishing Trust, 2nd Edition |page=426 |isbn=978-0877431725}}</ref> *Masúd - initially purchased as a youth by Khál-i Akbar, an uncle of the Báb, Masúd would serve Bahá'u'lláh in [[Acre, Israel|Acre]].<ref name="Afnan 2009, p.35">{{Citation |first=Abul-Qasim |last=Afnan |year=1999 |title= Black Pearls: Servants in the Household of the Bab and Baha'u'llah |publisher= Kalimat Press |location = |page= 35| isbn=1-890688-03-7}}</ref>

{{Use South African English|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Bahá'í sidebar}} The '''Bahá'í Faith in South Africa''' began with the holding of [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'í]] meetings in the country in 1911.{{cite web |author=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of South Africa | title = History of the Baha’i Faith in South Africa | work = Official Website | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of South Africa | year = 2014 | url = http://www.bahai.org.za/bahai-history-sa-early-years.html | accessdate = Mar 29, 2016}} A small population of Bahá'ís remained until 1950 when large numbers of international [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|Bahá'í pioneers]] settled in [[South Africa]]. In 1956, after members of various tribes in South Africa became Bahá'ís, a [[Bahá'í administration|regional Bahá'í Assembly]] which included South Africa was elected. Later each of the constituent countries successively formed their own independent Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]]. Then in 1995, after a prolonged period of growth and oppression during [[Apartheid]] and the [[Bantustan|homelands]] reuniting with South Africa, the Bahá'í National Spiritual Assembly of South Africa was formed. In 2005 Bahá'ís were estimated at about 240,100 adherents.{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} == Early history == 1911 marks the beginning of a presence of the Bahá'í Faith in South Africa at the home of Agnes Cook in Sea Point, [[Cape Town]]. Mr. and Mrs. William Fraetas from [[Muizenberg]] who had met [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], the son of the founder of the Bahá'í Faith, [[Bahá'u'lláh]], in New York, in 1912 came back to South Africa. === `Abdu'l-Bahá's Tablets of the Divine Plan === `Abdu'l-Bahá wrote a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the [[United States]] in 1916-1917; these letters were compiled together in the book ''[[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]''. The eighth and twelfth of the tablets mentioned [[Africa]] and were written on 19 April 1916 and 15 February 1917, respectively. Publication however was delayed in the United States until 1919—after the end of the [[World War I|First World War]] and the [[Spanish flu]]. The tablets were translated and presented by [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]] on 4 April 1919, and published in ''[[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]]'' magazine on 12 December 1919.{{cite book | last = Abbas | first = `Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab (trans. and comments) | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url =http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}} `Abdu'l-Bahá mentions Bahá'ís traveling "…especially from America to Europe, Africa, Asia and Australia, and travel through Japan and China. Likewise, from Germany teachers and believers may travel to the continents of America, Africa, Japan and China; in brief, they may travel through all the continents and islands of the globe"{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, IL |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-8.html.iso8859-1 | pages = 47–59 |origyear = 1916-17}} and " …the anthem of the oneness of the world of humanity may confer a new life upon all the children of men, and the tabernacle of universal peace be pitched on the apex of America; thus Europe and Africa may become vivified with the breaths of the Holy Spirit, this world may become another world, the body politic may attain to a new exhilaration…."{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, IL |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-12.html.iso8859-1 | pages = 82–89 |origyear = 1916-17}} After the death of `Abdu'l-Bahá Bahá'ís began to move to South Africa. By 1929 there were 6 small groups of Bahá'ís mainly due to [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] and travelling Bahá'ís, notably [[Martha Root]], in the Western Cape and near [[Johannesburg]]. The very first [[Local Spiritual Assembly|local Bahá'í Assembly]] formed in [[Pretoria]] in 1925 but was dissolved in 1931, and by about 1937 only one Bahá'í remained from that period, Mrs. Agnes Carey. Carey was a social worker for women prisoners who had been released from the Pretoria prison, and because of her staunchness in the religion she was later honoured with the title of "The Mother of the Bahá'ís of South Africa" by [[Shoghi Effendi]], who was appointed the leader of the religion after `Abdu'l-Bahá's death. Shoghi Effendi had travelled through South Africa in 1929 and 1940.{{cite news | author = Bahá'í International Community | title = Generation expresses gratitude | work = BWNS | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = 2003-12-31 | url = http://www.bahaiworldnews.org/story/270 | accessdate = 2008-03-19 }} In 1949 the painter [[Reginald Turvey]] returned to South Africa from [[Bahá'í Faith in the United Kingdom|England]] as a Bahá'í since 1936 through his association with the well-known painter [[Mark Tobey]] and lifelong friend [[Bernard Leach]]. Turvey was unaware of the existence of other Bahá'ís in South Africa including Agnes Carey. As a result, Turvey spent thirteen years believing he was the sole Bahá'í in South Africa. For his patience, devotion and subsequent services to the African Bahá'ís in his latter years, he was given the title of "The Father of the Bahá'ís of South Africa".{{cite journal | author = Lowell Johnson | title = Reginald Turvey, painter, South Africa | journal = BAFA | publisher = Bahá'í Faith and Arts and the Arts Dialogue | year = 2007 | url = http://bahai-library.com/bafa/t/turvey.htm | accessdate = 2008-03-19}} == Ten-Year Crusade == In 1953 Shoghi Effendi planned an international teaching plan termed the [[Ten Year Crusade]]. During the plan 65 pioneers from the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Germany]], [[New Zealand]] and [[England]] settled in South Africa. Many of the pioneers settled permanently in the country; [[William Sears (Bahá'í)|William Sears]] and his family, Harry and Margaret Ford, and Robert Miller and his family settled in Johannesburg; Ruth and Bishop Brown, who were Margaret Ford's mother and stepfather, settled in [[Durban]]. Lowell and Edith Johnson settled in Cape Town while Eleanor and Lyall Hadden settled in Pretoria. In 1954 in Pretoria, Klaas Mtsweni, a [[Zulu people|Zulu]], became the first indigenous South African to become a Bahá'í. In the succeeding years members of other South African ethnic groups including the [[Tswana people|Tswana]], the [[Xhosa people|Xhosa]], the southern and Northern [[Sotho people]]s, the [[Coloured]] ethnic group, the [[Cape Coloureds]], the [[Cape Malays]], and [[White people|White]], [[Afrikaner]]s became Bahá'ís. In 1959, after years of political involvement in [[African National Congress|ANC]] related organizations{{cite web| last = Igama Lamakhosikazi| first = Malibongwe| title = ANC Women's League - 50 Years of struggle| work = Official Webpage| publisher = The ANC Women's League| year = 2008| url = http://www.anc.org.za/wl/docs/50years.html| accessdate = 2008-03-19 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080220030006/http://www.anc.org.za/wl/docs/50years.html| archivedate = 20 February 2008}} in the 1950s, [[Bertha Mkize]] became a Bahá'í and withdrew from political involvements and instead [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneered]] to [[KwaZulu]] where she helped found 28 Bahá'í communities.{{Cite book| author = Universal House of Justice | title = Bertha Mkhize - 1889-1981| journal = The Bahá'í World| volume = XVIII| publisher = Bahá'í World Centre| page = 773| year = 1986| url = http://bahai-library.org/books/bw18/773-800.html| isbn = 0-85398-234-1}} In April 1956 the Bahá'í Faith was present in small numbers across 15 countries of Southern Africa including islands off Southern Africa. To administer these Bahá'í communities a regional governing body was elected in South Africa to cover them. Following the death of Shoghi Effendi and the election of the [[Universal House of Justice]], the islands of the Indian Ocean and the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland each formed their own [[National Spiritual Assembly]] in 1964. Starting in 1967 the number of Bahá'ís in the region was growing and it was necessary for new independent National Assemblies to be formed in those countries: 1967 - [[Zambia]]; 1970 - [[Botswana]], [[Malawi]], [[Zimbabwe]]; 1971 - [[Lesotho]]; 1972 - [[Madagascar]], [[Mauritius]], [[Reunion Island]]; 1977 - [[Swaziland]]; 1981 - [[Namibia]]; 1985 - [[Mozambique]]; 1991 - [[Angola]]; and in 1995 a re-united South Africa which included [[Bophuthatswana]], [[Ciskei]] and [[Transkei]]. == Apartheid == The 1959 [[Come Back, Africa]] film about Apartheid mentions the Bahá'í Faith as part of the discussion on the philosophical underpinnings of how the Africans were to respond to the challenge of Apartheid.{{cite web | last =Watson | first = Greg | title ="Come Back, Africa": First commercial film mentioning the Baha'i Faith | work =Essays and short articles | publisher =Baha'i Library Online | year =2013 | url =http://bahai-library.com/watson_come_back_africa | accessdate = 19 September 2014 }} The mention of the religion begins about 1 hr 10 min into the film, after the performance of [[Miriam Makeba]]. It is not known if the cause of the mention of the religion was scripted or improvised, and if by the choice of [[Lionel Rogosin]], the filmmaker (who may have encountered the religion in Israel or the USA) or the Africans themselves because of their exposure to the religion in the country. As another context for responding to the challenges of the period, it is known that the [[Sophiatown Renaissance]] was inspired by the [[Harlem Renaissance]]. The role of [[Alain Locke]] is key in that renaissance and Locke was a Bahá'í very involved in advocacy of Africans, African ideas, and internationalist thinking in line with the world-view of the religion.{{cite book|author=Christopher Buck|title=Alain Locke: Faith and Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JR_DF2MRlsIC&pg=PA64|year=2005|publisher=Kalimat Press|isbn=978-1-890688-38-7|pages=64, 198| series =Studies in Bábí and Bahá'í Religions | volume =18 | editor-last = Series Lee | editor-first =Anthony A.}}{{cite journal | last =Buck | first = Christopher | title =Alain Locke: Race Leader, Social Philosopher, Bahá'í Pluralist | journal =World Order | volume =36 | issue =3 | pages =7–36 | publisher =National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | year =2005 | url =http://christopherbuck.com/pdf/Buck_2005_Locke_World_Order.pdf | accessdate = 19 September 2014}} Faced with the segregated social pattern and laws of [[South Africa under apartheid|Apartheid]] in South Africa, the integrated population of Bahá'ís had to decide how to be composed in their administrative structures – whether the National Spiritual Assembly would be all black or all white. The Bahá'í community decided that instead of dividing the South African Bahá'í community into two population groups, one black and one white, they instead limited membership in the [[Bahá'í administration]] to black adherents, and placed the entire Bahá'í community under the leadership of its black population.{{cite book | author = Truth and Reconciliation Commission of South Africa Report | chapter = Regional Profile: Eastern Cape and Appendix: Statistics on Violations in the Eastern Cape | title = Truth and Reconciliation Commission of South Africa Report | volume =3 | pages = 32, 146 | date = 1998-10-29 | url = http://www.justice.gov.za/trc/report/finalreport/Volume%203.pdf | accessdate = 2008-03-19}}{{cite web | author = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of South Africa | title = Statement to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = 1997-11-19 | url = http://info.bahai.org/article-1-9-1-7.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110716093642/http://info.bahai.org/article-1-9-1-7.html | archive-date = 2011-07-16 | accessdate = 2017-09-25}}{{cite book | author = Truth and Reconciliation Commission of South Africa | title = Volume Four - Truth and Reconciliation Commission of South Africa Report | pages = 60, 65, 77, 80, 86 | nopp = yes | publisher = Truth and Reconciliation Commission of South Africa | date = 1998-10-29 | url = http://www.justice.gov.za/trc/report/finalreport/Volume%204.pdf | accessdate = 2008-03-19}} In 1997 the National Spiritual Assembly presented a Statement to the [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (South Africa)|Truth and Reconciliation Commission]] of South Africa which said in part:
Abhorring all forms of [[prejudice]] and rejecting any system of [[Racial segregation|segregation]], the Bahá'í Faith was introduced on a one-to-one basis and the community quietly grew during the apartheid years, without publicity. Despite the nature of the politics of that time, we presented our [[Bahá'í teachings|teachings]] on unity and the oneness of humankind to prominent individuals in politics, commerce and academia and leaders of thought including State Presidents.... [b]oth individual Bahá'ís and our administrative institutions were continually watched by the security police.... Our activities did not include opposition to the previous Government for involvement in partisan politics and opposition to government are explicitly prohibited by the sacred Texts of our Faith.... During the time when the previous [[Industrial Conciliation Act, 1956|Government prohibited integration within our communities]], rather than divide into separate administrative structures for each population group, we opted to limit membership of the Bahá'í Administration to the black adherents who were and remain in the majority of our membership and thereby placed the entire Bahá'í community under the stewardship of its black membership.... The pursuit of our objectives of unity and equality has not been without costs. The "white" Bahá'ís were often ostracized by their white neighbours for their association with "non-whites". The Black Bahá'ís were subjected to scorn by their black compatriots for their lack of political action and their complete integration with their white Bahá'í brethren. The most tragic loss to our community was the brutal execution of four of our adherents, at our places of worship, three in [[Mdantsane]] and one in [[Umtata]].{{cite news| last = Reber| first = Pat| title = Baha'i Church Shooting Verdicts in| publisher = South Africa Associated Press| date = 1999-05-02| url = http://bahai-library.com/newspapers/1999/031599-1.html| accessdate = 2008-03-19}}
The four Bahá'ís - three adults and one youth - murdered were Houshmand Anvari, Dr Shama Bakhshandegi, Vincent and Rias Razavi.{{Cite news | title = Former APLA Commander Denies Ordering Baha'i Attack | newspaper = South African Press Association | pages = | date = 1999-03-26| url = http://www.doj.gov.za/trc/media/1999/9903/s990326a.htm|accessdate=15 January 2015}} at the Bahá'í Faith Centre, [[Mdantsane]], Ciskei, on 13 March 1994.{{cite book| author = Truth and Reconciliation Commission of South Africa | title = Truth and Reconciliation Commission of South Africa Report| date = 1998-10-29| chapter = Victim Findings| pages = 13, 16| volume = 7| url = http://oldwww.parliament.gov.za/pls/portal30/docs/FOLDER/PARLIAMENTARY_INFORMATION/PUBLICATIONS/TRC/VICTIMS%2010-300.pdf | accessdate = 2008-03-20| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080409220940/http://oldwww.parliament.gov.za/pls/portal30/docs/FOLDER/PARLIAMENTARY_INFORMATION/PUBLICATIONS/TRC/VICTIMS%2010-300.pdf| archivedate= 9 April 2008 | deadurl= no}} for additional information see: * {{cite web| last =O’Malley | first = Padraig | authorlink =Padraig O’Malley| title =Chapter 7: Political Violence in the Era of Negotiations and Transition, 1990-1994 | date =29 October 1998 | url =http://www.nelsonmandela.org/omalley/index.php/site/q/03lv02167/04lv02264/05lv02335/06lv02357/07lv02372/08lv02379.htm| accessdate = 2013-09-03 }} * {{cite web| title =Amnesty Hearings | publisher =South Africa Broadcast Company (SABC) | date =2 April 1998 | url =http://sabctrc.saha.org.za/documents/amntrans/east_london/54715.htm | accessdate = 2013-09-03}} * {{cite news | title =APLA Cadres jailed 25 years for massacre | newspaper =ANC NewsBrief | publisher =ANC | date =20 April 1999 | url =http://bahai.uga.edu/News/042199-1.html | accessdate =2013-09-03}} * {{cite news| last =Blair | first = David| title = Mbeki sued as guerrilla he freed kills again | newspaper = UK Telegraph | date = 25 Nov 2005| url =https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/southafrica/1503950/Mbeki-sued-as-guerrilla-he-freed-kills-again.html | accessdate = 2013-09-03}} == Modern community == Since its inception the religion has had involvement in [[Socio-economic development (Bahá'í)|socio-economic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | accessdate = 2009-10-16}} promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development }} and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics. The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Peter Smith | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}} Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. Worldwide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socio-economic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482. Following the end of Apartheid the South African Bahá'í community in South Africa has also been involved in a variety of projects around the country. The [[Parliament of the World's Religions]] held its 1999 session in South Africa and the Bahá'ís helped in its organization and operation; Dr. Marks, the South African co-chair, is a Bahá'í.{{Cite news| last = Bamford | first = Suzanne | last2 = Rice | first2 = Muhtadia| title = In South Africa, the world's religions gather for dialogue and action | periodical = One Country | volume = 11 | issue = 3 |date=October–December 1999 | url = http://www.onecountry.org/e113/e11301as.htm }} In 2001 the [[Bahá'í International Community]] released two statements with regard to issues in South Africa. The first, on [[HIV/AIDS]] and [[Bahá'í teachings#Equality of women and men|gender equality]] issues particular to South Africa underscored the "[f]allacious notions about the naturally voracious sexual appetites of men" and "how culturally accepted social inequalities conspire with economic vulnerability to leave women and girls with little or no power to reject unwanted or unsafe sex. Yet, once infected with HIV/AIDS, women are often stigmatised as the source of the disease and persecuted, sometimes violently."{{Cite book|author=Bahá'í International Community |title=Statement on HIV/AIDS and Gender Equality |date=2001-06-25 |place=New York, United States |publisher=Bahá'í International Community |url=http://www.bci.org/southafrica/aids.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071107184416/http://www.bci.org/southafrica/aids.html |archivedate=7 November 2007 }} The second statement was on the issue of [[racism]].{{Cite book| author = Bahá'í International Community| contribution = One Same Substance: Consciously Creating a Global Culture of Unity| contribution-url = http://www.bic-un.bahai.org/01-0831.htm| title = World Conference Against Racism, Racial Discrimination, Xenophobia and Related Intolerance| date = 2001-08-31| place = Durban, South Africa| publisher = World Conference Against Racism, Racial Discrimination, Xenophobia and Related Intolerance| url = http://www.bic-un.bahai.org/01-0831.htm}} Bahá'ís also participated in the follow-up to the 1992 Rio Conference on the Environment - [[Earth Summit 2002]] held in South Africa in 2002. Some 30 representatives of six Bahá'í and Bahá'í-inspired organizations took part in the Summit including a statement entitled "Religion and Development at the Crossroads: Convergence or Divergence?". Delegations from the Bahá'í International Community, as well as the official Bahá'í communities of South Africa, [[Bahá'í Faith in Brazil|Brazil]], and [[Canada]] were accredited to the Summit as well as numerous sessions of Commissions of the [[United Nations]] on Sustainable Development.{{Cite news| author = Bahá'í International Community| title = Baha'is to stress spiritual values at World Summit on Sustainable Development| newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service| date = 2002-08-23| url = http://www.bahaiworldnews.org/story/170}}{{Cite book |author=Bahá'í International Community |contribution=Baha’í International Community |contribution-url=http://esa.un.org/coordination/ngo/session/views/viewer.asp?Document=E/C.2/2007/2/Add.23&number=2&view=2007_C2_Add_23_e.pdf&jumpto=2&session_db=..%5Cdb%5CPrevious_Sessions%5C..%5Csession_data.mdb |title=Quadrennial reports for the period 2002-2005 submitted through the Secretary-General pursuant to Economic and Social Council resolution 1996/31* - Note by the Secretary-General |date=2007-05-18 |pages=4–6 |publisher=United Nations |url=http://esa.un.org/coordination/ngo/session/views/viewer.asp?Document=E/C.2/2007/2/Add.23&number=2&view=2007_C2_Add_23_e.pdf&jumpto=2&session_db=..%5Cdb%5CPrevious_Sessions%5C..%5Csession_data.mdb |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611145030/http://esa.un.org/coordination/ngo/session/views/viewer.asp?Document=E%2FC.2%2F2007%2F2%2FAdd.23&number=2&view=2007_C2_Add_23_e.pdf&jumpto=2&session_db=..%5Cdb%5CPrevious_Sessions%5C..%5Csession_data.mdb |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 June 2011 }} During the Summit the experience of South African Bahá'í community with dealing with racism, education and gender inequality was offered.{{Cite book| title = Community Development Using Spiritually Based Indicators in The South African Baha’i Community| first = Farzin| last = Aghdasi| first2 = Abbas| last2 = Shaker| contribution = Community Development Using Spiritually Based Indicators in The South African Baha’i Community| contribution-url = http://www.bci.org/bahaistudies/Development.htm| date = 2002-08-09| publisher = Bahá'í International Community| url = http://www.bci.org/bahaistudies/Development.htm}} In 2004 Bahá'ís [[Mark Bamford]] and wife, co-writer and producer Suzanne Kay, and their two children, who had moved from the [[United States]] to live in Cape Town, South Africa made the movie [[Cape of Good Hope (film)|Cape of Good Hope]].{{cite web|publisher=Bahá'í World News Service|title=Couple put their faith into the picture|url=http://news.bahai.org/story/305|accessdate=2007-06-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070531124505/http://news.bahai.org/story/305| archivedate= 31 May 2007 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|last=Shuler|first=Deardra|title=Suzanne Kay and Mark Bamford: Bringing the Cape of Good Hope to America|url=http://www.afrocentricnews.com/html/kay_and_mark_bamford.html|publisher=Theodore Myles Publishing|accessdate=2007-06-25}} In 2007 two professional filmmakers finished an hourlong documentary about three Bahá'ís and how they practice their faith, and the film is being aired on television in South Africa and neighbouring countries. "Baha'i Faith: A Way Forward" was produced by Ryan and Leyla Haidarian at the request of the [[South African Broadcasting Corporation]], which has licensed rights to the documentary for two years.{{Cite news| author = Bahá'í International Community| title = South African film shows faith in action| newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service| date = 2007-08-19| url = http://news.bahai.org/story/573}} In addition to a variety if singular events the Bahá'ís engaged in a number of annual events. The perennial youth service and arts project "Beyond Words" has toured South African Bahá'í communities since 2000.{{Cite news|last=Varjavandi |first=Roya |title=Beyond Words and the Spirit of Africa |periodical=The Scottish Bahá'í |issue=35 |date=2004-02-17 |url=http://www.breacais.demon.co.uk/sbn/sbn35/sab1.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061003191021/http://www.breacais.demon.co.uk/sbn/sbn35/sab1.htm |archivedate=3 October 2006 }} The Association for Bahá’í Studies in Southern Africa held its seventh annual conference in 2006 at Bloemfontein, South Africa, including talks by John Grayzel, Chair, Bahá’í Studies, [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] and [[Institution of the Counsellors|Continental Counsellor]] Enos Makhele.{{Cite book| author = members of the Association for Bahá’í Studies in Southern Africa| title = Conference Programme with Abstracts and Notes from Presentations| year = 2006| place = Bloemfontein, South Africa| publisher = Association for Bahá’í Studies in Southern Africa| url = http://www.bci.org/bahaistudies/Conference%20Report-abstracts%20and%20notes-2006.htm }} === Jubiliee === In 2003 the Bahá'í community of South Africa celebrated their Golden Jubilee (50 year anniversary of the community) in [[Phokeng]] which was followed by satellite festivities in eight cities:[[Bloemfontein]], Cape Town, Durban, Pretoria, Johannesburg, [[Sabie]], [[Umtata]], and [[Mafikeng]].{{Cite news | last = Woodhurst| first = Alan | title = Bahá’í Activities in South Africa | periodical = Bahá'í Journal of the Bahá'í Community of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland| volume = 20 | issue = 5| year = 2004| url =http://www.bahaijournal.org.uk/BJ200401/africa.htm | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20061014081414/http://www.bahaijournal.org.uk/BJ200401/africa.htm | archivedate =2006-10-14 }} The National Spiritual Assembly's own Golden Jubilee included a 2006 commemoration by [[Thabo Mbeki]] on behalf of the Government and people of South Africa to say congratulations and best wishes to the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of South Africa.{{cite web| author = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of South Africa|author2=President of South Africa |author3=Mr. Thabo Mbeki | title = A message from Mr Thabo Mbeki, the President of South Africa| work = Official Webpage| publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of South Africa| url = http://www.bahai.org.za/cm/node/18 | accessdate = 2008-03-21 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080408200300/http://www.bahai.org.za/cm/node/18| archivedate= 8 April 2008 | deadurl= no}} === South African regional conference === Regional conferences were called for by the [[Universal House of Justice]] 20 October 2008 to celebrate recent achievements in grassroots community-building and to plan their next steps in organizing in their home areas. Just two weeks later twin conferences were held - one in South Africa and the other in [[Bahá'í Faith in Kenya|Kenya]]. One regional conference was hosted by the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of South Africa in Johannesburg in November 2008 and attracted over 1000 Bahá'ís from Angola, Botswana, La Reunion, Lesotho, Madagascar, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, Seychelles, South Africa, and Swaziland.{{Cite news| author = Bahá'í International Community | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Big turnout for regional Baha’i conferences | newspaper = Bahá'í International News Service | date = 2008-11-11 | url = http://www.bahaiworldnews.org/story/668}} == Demographics == Estimates of the Bahá'ís in South Africa range from around 201,000{{cite web |year=2007-8 |title=Country Profile: South Africa (Republic of South Africa) |place=Republic of South Africa |publisher=Religious Intelligence |url=http://www.religiousintelligence.co.uk/country/?CountryID=158 |accessdate=2015-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090919025324/http://www.religiousintelligence.co.uk/country/?CountryID=158 |archivedate=19 September 2009 }} to about 240,100 adherents by the [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]. == Publications == * '''My African Heart''' by Bonnie Fitzpatrick-Moore, Paperback, 196 pages, {{ISBN|978-1-874801-86-3}}, December 1999, published by Baha'i Publishing Trust {{Infobox religious building | building_name = Bairat Temple | image = Buddhist Temple Viratnagar.jpg
| alt = | caption = Remains of Bairat Temple | map_type = India Rajasthan#India | relief = yes | map_size = 250 | location = [[India]] | coordinates = {{coord|27.417116|N|76.16229|E|display=inline,title}} | religious_affiliation = [[Buddhism]] | rite = | region = [[Maharashtra]] | state = | province = | territory = | prefecture = | sector = | district = | circle = | municipality = | consecration_year = 3rd century BCE | status = Ruins | functional_status = Artifacts removed | heritage_designation = | leadership = | website = | architecture = | architect = | architecture_type = | architecture_style = | general_contractor = | facade_direction = | groundbreaking = | year_completed = | construction_cost = | specifications = | capacity = | length = | width = | width_nave = | height_max = | dome_quantity = | dome_height_outer = | dome_height_inner = | dome_dia_outer = | dome_dia_inner = | minaret_quantity = | minaret_height = | spire_quantity = | spire_height = | materials = | nrhp = | added = | refnum = | designated = }} '''Bairat Temple''' is a freestanding Buddhist temple, a [[Chaityagriha]], located about a mile southwest of the city [[Bairat]], [[Rajasthan]], [[India]], on a hill locally called "Bijak-ki-Pahari" ("Hill of the Inscription").<ref name=Asijaipur/><ref name=ASI/> The temple is of a circular type, formed of a central [[stupa]] surrounded by a circular colonnade and an enclosing wall.<ref name=BA233/> It was built during the time of [[Ashoka]] in the 3rd century BCE, and near it were found two of Ashoka's [[Minor Rock Edicts]], the Bairat and the Calcutta-Bairat Minor Rock Edicts.<ref name=BA233>Le Huu Phuoc, 2010, p.233-237</ref> The temple is an important marker of the [[architecture of India]].
==A rare circular stand-alone temple== Early Chaitya halls are known from the 3rd century BCE. They generally followed a circular or [[apsidal]] plan, and were either rock-cut or freestanding.<ref name=AH>{{cite book |last1=Chakrabarty |first1=Dilip K. |title=India: An Archaeological History: Palaeolithic Beginnings to Early Historic Foundations |date=2009 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=9780199088140 |page=421 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wPQtDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT421 |language=en}}</ref> Temples —built on elliptical, circular, quadrilateral, or apsidal plans— were initially constructed using brick and timber.<ref name=Chandra>Chandra (2008)</ref> Some temples of timber with [[wattle-and-daub]] may have preceded them, but none remain to this day.<ref name=BA233/>
Today, only the foundation of the temple remains.<ref name=BA233/> The circular temple was located inside a rectangular enclosure wall, and had an outer diameter of 5.6 meters.<ref name=BA233/> It was built around a small stupa at the centre, with a diameter of 1.6 meters.<ref name=BA233/> There was also an internal circle of 26 wooden octagonal columns surrounding the stupa.<ref name=BA233/><ref name=Asijaipur>{{cite web |url=http://asijaipurcircle.nic.in/Bairat%20-%20Excavated%20site.html|title=ASI Notice}}</ref> The layout created two ''[[pradaksina]]'' circular paths for devotional deambulation. The global shape of the temple has been inferred from more or less contemporary reliefs of such buildings from [[Bharhut]], or from rock-cut temples at [[Kondivite]], [[Tulja caves]] or [[Guntupalli caves]].<ref name=BA233/>
Its has been suggested that this circular design with columns was derived from the similar design of the Greek [[Tholos (architecture)|Tholos]].<ref name=BA233/> However local circular hut designs are a more probable source of inspiration.<ref name=BA233/>
<gallery mode=packed> Bairat temple and rock.jpg|Another view of the remains. Bairat Temple plan.jpg|Temple plan. Bairat Temple reconstitution.jpg|Drawing of original temple File:Bharhut circular Temple.jpg|Relief of a circular temple, [[Bharhut]], circa 100 BCE. Bharhut Mahabodhi Temple.jpg|Early circular [[Mahabodhi Temple]], [[Bharhut]], circa 100 BCE. </gallery>
===Minor Rock Edict of Ashoka=== A [[Minor Rock Edict]] of [[Ashoka]] (the unique Minor Rock Edict No.3) was found in close proximity to the Temple: the Bairat-Calcutta Edict, also called the Bhabru Edict, from the name of a nearby village.<ref name=ASI>{{cite book |title=Archaeological Survey Of India Four Reports Made During The Years 1862 - 63 - 64 - 65 Volume Ii |date=1871 |pages=242–248 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Four_Reports_Made_During_the_Years_1862.html?id=3s4OAAAAQAAJ}}</ref> Dating to circa 250 BCE, the edict was found just in front of the remains of the Bairat Temple, on the lower platform located between the temple and the cannon-shaped large rock ({{coord|27.417124|76.162569|display=inline}}).<ref name=ASI/> The presence of this inscription, its date and its Buddhist content, help date the temple with a high level of certainty, as well as confirm its Buddhist affiliation.<ref name=ASI/>
The Edict, relocated since the 19th century to the [[Asiatic Society|Asiatic Society of Bengal]] in [[Calcutta]] (hence the name "Calcutta-Bairat Edict)", is the only one of its kind, describing Buddhist scriptures recommended by Ashoka for study. It reads:
[[File:Bhabru inscription.jpg|thumb|The [[Minor Rock Edict]] of Ashoka, found on the platform in front of the temple.<ref name=ASI/>]] [[File:Bairat-Calcutta Edict discovery spot.jpg|thumb|The inscription was found on a rock on the platform between the Bairat Temple and the huge cannon-shaped rock in front of it.<ref name=ASI/>]] [[File:Bhabru inscription of the Buddha word.jpg|thumb|upright=0.5|The word "Buddha" in the Bairat Edict. [[Brahmi script]].]] {{quote| The [[Magadha]] king Priyadarsin, having saluted the [[Samgha]] hopes they are both well and comfortable.
It is known to you, Sirs, how great is my reverence and faith in the [[Buddha]], the [[Dharma]] (and) the [[Samgha]].
Whatsoever, Sirs, has been spoken by the blessed Buddha, all that is quite well spoken.
But, Sirs, what would indeed appear to me (to be referred to by the words of the scripture): "thus the true Dharma will be of long duration", that I feel bound to declare:
The following expositions of the Dharma, Sirs, (viz.) the ''Vinaya-Samukasa'' ("The Exaltation of Discipline"), the ''Aliya-vasas'' ("The Ideal Mode of Life"), the ''Anagata-bhayas'' ("Fears to Come"), the ''Muni-gathas'' ("The Songs of the Hermit"), the ''Moneya-Suta'' ("Discourse on the Hermit Life"), the ''Upatisa-pasina'' ("The Questions of Upatishya"), and the ''Laghulovada'' ("The Sermon to [[Rahula]]") which was spoken by the blessed Buddha concerning falsehood, — I desire, Sirs, that many groups of monks and (many) nuns may repeatedly listen to these expositions of the Dharma and may reflect (on them).
In the same way both laymen and laywomen (should act).
For the following (purpose), Sirs, am I causing this to be written, (viz.) in order that they may know my intention. |Adapted from Inscriptions of Asoka. New Edition by E. Hultzsch 1925 [https://archive.org/stream/InscriptionsOfAsoka.NewEditionByE.Hultzsch/HultzschCorpusAsokaSearchable#page/n349/mode/2up p.172] Public Domain }}
This edict was the basis for the efforts at deciphering [[Brahmi]], led by [[James Prinsep]] in 1837.<ref>Proceedings of the Meetings of the Session, Volume 24, Indian Historical Records Commission, 1948 "the discovery at Bairat of the Asokan inscription which, in the hands of James Prinsep, became the key for unravelling and deciphering the edicts of King Piyadasi"</ref> A commemorative plaque [https://i0.wp.com/www.kolkataonwheels.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/DSC_0042.jpg is visible at the Asiatic Society].
==Other circular temples== Some of the earliest free-standing temples may have been of a circular type. [[Ashoka]] also built the [[Mahabodhi Temple]] in [[Bodh Gaya]] circa 250 BCE, also a circular structure, in order to protect the [[Bodhi tree]] under which the [[Buddha]] had found enlightenment. Representations of this early temple structure are found [[:File:Adoration_of_the_Diamond_Throne_and_the_Bodhi_Tree_Bharhut_relief.jpg|on a 100 BCE relief]] sculpted on the railing of the stupa at [[Bharhut|Bhārhut]], as well as in [[Sanchi]].<ref>"Sowing the Seeds of the Lotus: A Journey to the Great Pilgrimage Sites of Buddhism, Part I" by John C. Huntington. ''Orientations'', November 1985 pg 61</ref> From that period the [[Diamond throne]] remains, an almost intact slab of [[sandstone]] decorated with reliefs, which Ashoka had established at the foot of the [[Bodhi tree]].<ref name="Huu Phuoc">Buddhist Architecture, Huu Phuoc Le, Grafikol, 2010 [https://books.google.com/books?id=9jb364g4BvoC&pg=PA240 p.240]</ref><ref name="Ching">A Global History of Architecture, Francis D. K. Ching, Mark M. Jarzombek, Vikramaditya Prakash, John Wiley & Sons, 2017 [https://books.google.com/books?id=SPqKDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT570 p.570ff]</ref> These circular-type temples were also found in later rock-hewn caves such as [[Tulja Caves]] or [[Guntupalli Group of Buddhist Monuments|Guntupalli]].<ref name=BA233/>
<gallery> File:Adoration_of_the_Diamond_Throne_and_the_Bodhi_Tree_Bharhut_relief.jpg|Ashoka's [[Mahabodhi Temple]] and [[Diamond throne]] in [[Bodh Gaya]], built circa 250 BCE. [[Bharhut]] frieze. File:Bodhi tree temple depicted in Sanchi Stupa 1 Southern gateway.jpg|Bodhi tree temple depicted in Sanchi, Stupa 1, Southern gateway. File:Andhra pradesh, santuario a più piani, da ghantasala, 90-110 ca..JPG|Relief of a multi-storied temple, 2nd century CE, [[Ghantasala, Krishna district|Ghantasala]] Stupa.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hardy |first1=Adam |title=Indian Temple Architecture: Form and Transformation : the Karṇāṭa Drāviḍa Tradition, 7th to 13th Centuries |date=1995 |publisher=Abhinav Publications |isbn=9788170173120 |page=39 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aU0hCAS2-08C&pg=PA41 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Le |first1=Huu Phuoc |title=Buddhist Architecture |date=2010 |publisher=Grafikol |isbn=9780984404308 |page=238 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9jb364g4BvoC&pg=PA238 |language=en}}</ref> File:Tulja Lena Chaitya remains.jpg|thumb|left|Remains of the circular rock-hewn circular [[Chaitya]] with columns, [[Tulja caves]]. </gallery>
==Apsidal temples== Another early free-standing temple in India, this time [[apsidal]] in shape, appears to be [[:Commons:category:Sanchi Temple 40|Temple 40]] at [[Sanchi]], which is also dated to the 3rd century BCE.<ref name="BA147">Buddhist Architecture, Lee Huu Phuoc, Grafikol 2010, p.147</ref> It was an [[apsidal]] temple built of timber on top of a high rectangular stone platform, 26.52x14x3.35 metres, with two flights of stairs to the east and the west. The temple was burnt down sometime in the 2nd century BCE.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Abram |first1=David |last2=(Firm) |first2=Rough Guides |title=The Rough Guide to India |date=2003 |publisher=Rough Guides |isbn=9781843530893 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kAMik_6LbwUC&pg=PA393 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Marshall |first1=John |title=Guide to Sanchi |date=1955 |url=https://archive.org/stream/in.gov.ignca.4365/4365#page/n153/mode/2up}}</ref> This type of apsidal structure was also adopted for most of the cave temple ([[Chaitya-griha]]s), as in the 3rd century BCE [[Barabar Caves]] and most caves thereafter, with side, and then frontal, entrances.<ref name=BA233/> A freestanding apsidal temple remains to this day, although in a modified form, in the [[Trivikrama Temple]] in [[Ter, Maharashtra]].<ref name=BA>{{cite book |last1=Le |first1=Huu Phuoc |title=Buddhist Architecture |date=2010 |publisher=Grafikol |isbn=9780984404308 |page=237 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9jb364g4BvoC&pg=PA237 |language=en}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Architecture|India|Buddhism}} * [http://asijaipurcircle.nic.in/Bairat%20-%20Excavated%20site.html ASI notice]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== * Chandra, Pramod (2008), ''South Asian arts'', Encyclopædia Britannica. {{Edicts of Ashoka}}

{{Zoroastrianism}} '''Barashnûm''', or '''Barashnûm nû shaba'''{{Pronunciation-needed}}<!-- as IPA -->, is a [[Zoroastrian]] [[Ritual purification|purification]] [[ritual]] which lasts nine nights. Because the ritual lasts nine nights, it is known as '''Barashnûm nû shaba''' or "Barashnûm of the nine nights".<ref name="vendidadp119">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 119</ref>
== Etymology ==
Barashnûm is a [[Zend]] word meaning "top of the head".<ref name="vendidadp133">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 133</ref> The whole ritual is named "Barashnûm" because purification starts from the head of the person, which is the first part in his body which is purified.<ref name="vendidadp133" />
== Purpose ==
In pre-Islamic times, Barashnûm was used to purify men and women who had been defiled by contact with dead matter.<ref name="vendidadp119" /> But the [[Parsis]] of [[India]] used Barashnûm not only to purify people defiled by the dead but also to purify adolescents during the ''Nû zûdî '' or [[Navjote]] when they reach the age of fifteen.<ref name="vendidadp119" /> The ritual is undertaken in order to cleanse the subject of the impurities that are believed to have befallen him or her during the time he or she had spent as a foetus in the maternal womb and accompanies the tying of the [[kushti]] which marks the entry of a child into adulthood.<ref name="vendidadp119" />
== The ritual ==
Fargard 9 of the [[Vendidad]] prescribes the requirements for the Barashnûm ritual. It prescribes that a series of six holes two feet deep if it was summer season and four feet deep if it was winter season be dug at a distance of three feet from each other and a series of three holes at a distance of nine feet from the other six.<ref name="vendidadp121">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 121</ref> The hole at the most extreme corner should be situated at a distance of at least thirty paces from the [[holy fire]] or consecrated [[barsom]] and three paces from "clean" Zoroastrians.<ref name="vendidadp120">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 120</ref> The holes should lie in a north-south direction and the first six are to be filled with ''[[gōmēz]]'' while the other three are to be filled with water.
Holes 4-6 should be separated from holes 7-9 through a ring of 3 [[furrows]] arranged concentrically which act as a protective barrier.<ref name="vendidadp122">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 122</ref> Similarly, holes 4-9 were to be separated from holes 1-3 by a barrier of 3 furrows. This arrangement is called the Barashnûm-gâh and is to be separated from cleaner pastures by an outer enclosure comprising a series of three furrows.<ref name="vendidadp122" />
The impure person should walk to each of the holes containing ''gomez'' in turn while reciting [[Yasna]] 49 of the Avesta while the Zoroastrian priest recites the same from outside the furrow surrounding the hole<ref name="vendidadp122" /> and sprinkles gomez upon the impure person on completion of each recitation.<ref name="vendidadp123-5">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 123 - 125</ref> The priest purifies the brows, the back of the skull, jaws, ears, the shoulders, arm-pits, chest, back, nipples, ribs, hips, genitals, thighs, knees, legs, ankles, feet and toes of the subject by sprinkling a few drops of gomez upon them.<ref name="vendidadp123-5" /> Once the purification is complete, the subject recites the [[Ahunwar]], Kem-na-Mazda, Kem verethrem ja and other principal prayers of the Zoroastrians.<ref name="vendidadp126">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 126</ref>
The defiled person, then sits inside the outer enclosure but outside the ones enclosing holes 4-9 and rubs dust all over his body for it to dry.<ref name="vendidadp127">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 127</ref> He, then enters the inner furrows and steps in the holes 4-9 cleansing himself with the water contained in them.<ref name="vendidadp127" /> Once the ritual is complete, he may come out of the Barashnûm-gâh and is permitted to return to his house.<ref name="vendidadp128">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 128</ref> However, he is confined to a corner of the house called Armêsht-gah<ref name="vendidadp133" /> for nine nights.<ref name="vendidadp128" /> During this period, he is prohibited from contacting water, fire, earth, cow, trees and other Zoroastrians as he is considered to be impure and his contact is believed to defile the objects around him.<ref name="vendidadp128" /> Once every three days, he is enjoined to bathe himself and wash his clothes in ''gomez'' and water as a part of the purification ritual.<ref name="vendidadp128" /> On the completion of his third bath, he is considered to be "completely purified" and is permitted to lead a normal life.<ref name="vendidadp128" />
== Fee for the cleanser == The fee to be paid to the priest who cleanses an impure person is also specified in the Fargard 9 of the Vendidad.<ref name="vendidadp129">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 129</ref> The Fargard decrees that a fellow defiled priest should be cleansed in return for blessings, the lord of province for the payment of a camel, the lord of a town for the payment of a horse, the lord of a [[borough]] for the payment of a bull, and a householder in return for a three-year-old cow.<ref name="vendidadp129" />
The Vendidad also specifies the punishment to be handed to a priest who has erred in the rituals.
{{quotation|The cleanser who has not performed the cleansing according to the rites, shall be taken to a desert place; there they shall nail him with four nails, they shall take off the skin from his body, and cut off his head. If he has performed Patet for his sin, he shall be holy (that is, he shall go to paradise); if he has not performed Patet, he shall stay in hell till the day of resurrection<ref name="vendidadp27">[[#Darmesteter|Darmesteter]], Pg 27</ref>|[[Vendidad|The Vendidad]], Fargard III}}
== Notes ==
