{{Islam and other religions}} [[Islam]] is an [[Abrahamic religion]] founded in the Arabian peninsula, while [[Sikhism]] is a [[Dharmic religion]] founded in the [[Indian subcontinent]]. Islam means "submission" (to the will of God).<ref>{{Cite web|title = Online Etymology Dictionary|url = http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=Islam&allowed_in_frame=0|website = www.etymonline.com|accessdate = 2015-06-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Islam: The Religion and The People|author1=Lewis, Barnard |author2=Churchill, Buntzie Ellis |publisher = Wharton|year = 2009|isbn = 9780132230858|location = |pages = 8}}</ref> The word [[Sikh]] is derived from a Sanskrit word meaning 'disciple', or one who learns.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Online Etymology Dictionary|url = http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=Sikh|website = www.etymonline.com|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref>
Both religions are monotheistic. [[Sufi|Sufi Muslims]] and [[Sikh|Sikhs]] believe that the 'One' creator permeates the creation.<ref name="sufism">{{cite|title=Sufism: A Short Introduction|author=William Chittick|}}</ref><ref name=jj1/><ref name=sm1/> [[Salafism|Salafi Muslims]] on the other hand disagree. Sufi Muslims differ from Sikhs in that they believe that God manifests his attributes, namely [[Names_of_God_in_Islam#Lists_of_names|the 99 names or attributes]] through his creation.<ref name="sufism"/> According to Salafi Muslims, God's attributes are separate from his creation as he is only above his [[Throne_of_God#Islam|Throne]].<ref>{{citation|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=qTiTDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA43|title=Chinese Muslims and the Global Ummah: Islamic Revival and Ethnic Identity|author=Alexander Stewart|page=43|}}</ref> Islam believes that [[Muhammad]] was the last prophet, to whom the [[Quran]] was revealed by God in the 7th century CE. Sikhism was founded in the 15th century CE by [[Guru Nanak]] and the [[Guru Granth Sahib]] is the scripture followed by Sikhs as "The Living Guru".<ref name=jj1/><ref name=g18/>
In Islam, the legal system based on the Quran and the Sunnah is known as [[Sharia]]; there is no such legal system mentioned in Guru Granth Sahib. [[Salah|Daily prayers]] are one of the pillars of Islam and is mandatory for eligible Muslims.<ref>{{cite book | last=Fisher | first=Mary | title=Living religions : an encyclopedia of the world's faiths | year=1997 | isbn=978-1-86064-148-0 | page=353}}</ref> Baptized Sikhs read the five banis (prayers) as part of their daily routine, [[Nitnem]]. Islam requires annual [[zakah]] (alms giving) by Muslims.<ref>{{cite book | last=Rai | first=Priya | title=Sikhism and the Sikhs | publisher=Greenwood Press |year=1989 | isbn=978-0-313-26130-5 | pages=230–233}}</ref> Kirat Karna (doing an honest livelihood - earning honestly without any sort of corruption), Naam Japna (to chant and meditate on Naam, read and follow "The One") and [[Vand Chakna|Vand Chhako]] (Selfless service (Sewa) and sharing with others) are fundamental to Sikhism given by Guru Nanak Dev Ji. Pilgrimage (to Mecca) is a crucial part of Islam, while Sikhism denounces pilgrimages, circumcision and rituals. .<ref name="D.S Chahal Editors: John Peppin etc. 2004">{{cite book | author=D.S Chahal (Editors: John Peppin etc.) | title=Religious perspectives in bioethics | publisher=Taylor & Francis | location=London u.a | year=2004 | isbn=978-0-415-54413-9}}</ref> According to Guru Gobind Singh, the tenth Sikh Guru stated in his 52 Hukamnamas that a Sikh should undertake Pilgrimages to Sikh Gurdwaras.
There has been a history of constructive influence and conflict between Islam and Sikhism. The Sikh scripture ''[[Guru Granth Sahib]]'' includes teachings from Muslims, namely saints [[Fariduddin Ganjshakar|Bhagat Farid]]), a Sufi Muslim of the [[Chishti]] Sufi order and [[Kabir]].<ref name=shapiro924>{{cite book|last=Shapiro|first=Michael|year=2002|title=Songs of the Saints from the Adi Granth|publisher=Journal of the American Oriental Society|pages=924, 925}}</ref><ref name=deol/><ref>{{cite book|author=Pashaura Singh|title=The Guru Granth Sahib: Canon, Meaning and Authority |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HMvXAAAAMAAJ |year=2000|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-564894-2|pages=174–180}}</ref> In contrast, of [[Sikh gurus|total 10 Sikh gurus]], <ref name=IslamistPersecution1/><ref name=IslamistPersecution3/><ref name=IslamistPersecution4/><ref name=IslamistPersecution5/> two gurus - [[Guru Arjan]] and [[Guru Tegh Bahadur]] - were tortured and executed for refusing to convert to Islam,<ref name="Singh2003"/><ref name=IslamistPersecution2/> children of [[Guru Gobind Singh]] were killed,<ref name=pri/><ref name=IslamistPersecution6/> along with numerous other revered figures of Sikhism such as [[Banda Bahadur]], [[Bhai Mati Das]], [[Bhai Sati Das]] and [[Bhai Dayala]]).<ref name=IslamistPersecution5/><ref name=pri/><ref name=IslamistPersecution6/> for refusing to convert to Islam,<ref name=IslamistPersecution8>Pashaura Singh (2005), Understanding the Martyrdom of Dhan Dhan Sri Guru Arjan Dev Ji, Journal of Punjab Studies, 12(1), pages 29-62</ref><ref name=IslamistPersecution1/><ref name=IslamistPersecution6/><ref name=pri/> and for opposing the persecution of [[Sikhs]] and [[Hindus]].<ref name=IslamistPersecution9>{{cite journal | last =McLeod | first =Hew | title =Sikhs and Muslims in the Punjab | journal =South Asia: Journal of South Asian Studies | volume =22 | issue =s1 | pages =155–165 | year =1987 | doi =10.1080/00856408708723379 }}</ref><ref name=IslamistPersecution2/><ref name=IslamistPersecution3/><ref name=IslamistPersecution5/> Some sources contest such a historical rendition.<ref name="conversion3">{{citation|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=f9D4Ob1YcJgC&pg=PA73&|title=South Asia: An Environmental History|author=Christopher V. Hill|page=73|others=quote: "He did not, however, introduce forced conversion..."}}</ref>
== Comparison ==
===Belief===
==== God ==== Sikhism believes that God is formless (''nirankar'').<ref name=jj1>{{cite book | last=Johal | first=Jagbir | title=Sikhism today | publisher=Continuum | year=2011 | isbn=978-1-4411-8140-4 | pages=1–2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Eleanor Nesbitt|title=Sikhism: A Very Short Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4ysRDAAAQBAJ|year=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-106276-6|page=24}}</ref> It has been called a form of [[pantheism]],<ref name=sm1>{{Google books|QGkoAAAAYAAJ|Sikhism in Its Relation to Muhammadanism|page=12}}</ref> as well as [[monotheism]].<ref name=jj1/> God in the nirgun aspect is without attributes, unmanifest, not seen, but all pervading and permeating, omnipresent. God in the sargun aspect is manifest has attributes, qualities, and seen in the whole creation. [Ik Onkar There is only one God, he is the eternal truth, he is without fear, he is without hate, immortal, without form, Beyond birth and death...]
Islam believes in one God with Muhammad as his last messenger. It denies other gods, and is strictly monotheistic (''[[tawḥīd]]'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t125/e2356?_hi=0&_pos=2 |title=From the article on Tawhid in Oxford Islamic Studies Online |publisher=Oxfordislamicstudies.com |date=2008-05-06 |accessdate=2014-08-24}}</ref><ref name= Ruthven14/> This Islamic doctrine is a part of its [[Shahada]].<ref name= Ruthven14>{{cite book|author=Malise Ruthven|title=Historical Atlas of Islam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wT1xGHPyMA8C |year=2004|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-01385-8|page=14}}</ref>
[Say: He is Allah, the One and Only; (1) Allah, the Eternal, Absolute; (2) He begetteth not, nor is He begotten; (3) And there is none like unto Him. (4)] (Quran Al-Ikhlas)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.islam101.com/quran/yusufAli/QURAN/112.htm |title=112. The Unity, Sincerity, Oneness Of Allah |publisher=Islam101.com}}</ref>
====Guru and Messengers====
Sikhism reveres Guru Nanak as the embodiment of the one divine creator lord on earth which is manifest in the ten forms of the ten [[Sikh gurus|Gurus of Sikhs]]. Sikhism accepts that there were divine messengers, including [[Krishna]], [[Moses]], [[Jesus]] and [[Mohammed]] in other religions.<ref name=jj1/>
Islam believes that before Muhammad there were many messengers of God, Muhammad was the last messenger, and Quran was the last revelation to the last prophet.<ref name=fg204>{{cite book | last=Gülen | first=Fethullah | title=The Messenger of God Muhammad : an analysis of the Prophet's life | year=2005 | isbn=978-1-932099-83-6 | page=204}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author1=Scott Noegel |author2=Brannon M. Wheeler | title=Historical dictionary of prophets in Islam and Judaism | publisher=Scarecrow | year=2002 | isbn=978-0-8108-4305-9 | pages=227–229}}</ref>
==== Duties/Articles of Faith ==== The [[Five Pillars of Islam]] are duties incumbent on every [[Muslim]]. These duties are [[Shahada]] (testimony that "There is no god but God and Muhammad is the messenger of God"),<ref name="jea" /> [[Salat]] (prayers), [[Zakat]] (Giving of Alms), [[Sawm]] ([[Fasting during Ramadan]]) and [[Hajj]] (pilgrimage to [[Mecca]]). These five practices are essential to [[Sunni Islam]]; [[Shia Islam|Shi'a Muslims]] subscribe to eight ritual practices which substantially overlap with the five Pillars.<ref>See: * Mumen (1987), p.178, {{cite encyclopedia |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Pillars-of-Islam | title=Pillars of Islam | encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia Britannica Online | accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Knight|first=Ian |author2=Scollins|editor=Richard|title=Queen Victoria's Enemies: India No.3 |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0850459435|accessdate=17 January 2011|edition=Paperback |series=Men-at-arms|date=23 March 1990|publisher=Osprey Publishing; illustrated edition|isbn=0-85045-943-5 |page=15}}</ref>
The three duties of Sikhs are [[Naam Japna]] (meditating on [[Waheguru|Waheguru's]] name), [[Kirat Karni]] (earn honest living) and [[Vand Chakna]] (sharing one's earning with others).<ref>{{cite web | title=Religion: Sikhism | website=BBC | date=1970-01-01 | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/sikhism/beliefs/beliefs.shtml | accessdate=2015-06-04}}</ref> Baptized Sikhs, the Amritdharis are belonging to the Khalsa Panth. They wear the five articles of faith, known as 5 K´s, (1. Kes, uncut hair and beard, 2. Kangha, a wooden comb, 3. Kara, a bracelet worn around the wrist, 4. Kirpan, a small dagger and 5. Kachera, a special underwear). The Khalsa Panth was created on Vaisakhi 1699 by the tenth Sikh Guru, Guru Gobind Singh. The baptized Sikhs have a set of seven sikh prayers, called Nitnem, which they practise on a daily basis, this is mandatory.
====Social beliefs==== Sikhism has an ambivalent attitude towards miracles and rejects any form of discrimination within and against other religions.<ref name="Baksh">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CFKYFcosJUsC|title=Islam and Other Major World Religions|first=Kaiyume|last=Baksh|date=1 January 2007|publisher=Trafford Publishing|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref name="Baksh"/> Sikhism does not believe in rituals, but is permissive of traditions.<ref name=g18>{{cite book | first=Gurapreet| last=Singh | title=The soul of Sikhism | year=2003 | isbn=978-81-288-0085-6 | page=18}}</ref>
Sikhism rejects asceticism and celibacy.<ref name=dc1/> The Sikhism founder Guru Nanak adopted the Indic ideas on rebirth, and taught the ideas of [[reincarnation]].<ref name=dc1>{{cite book | last=Carmody | first=Denise | title=Ways to the center : an introduction to world religions |year=2013 | isbn=978-1-133-94225-2 | page=339}}</ref> Adi Granth of Sikhism recognizes and includes spiritual wisdom from other religions.<ref name=g18/><ref name="Juergensmeyer 2006">{{cite book | last=Juergensmeyer | first=Mark | title=The Oxford handbook of global religions | publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2006 | isbn=978-0-19-976764-9}}</ref>{{page needed|date=October 2015}} Islam warns against wrongful innovation ([[bid‘ah]]) to what is revealed in the Quran and the Hadiths.<ref name=g18/>
Islam considers itself to be a perfect and final religion.<ref name="Juergensmeyer 2006"/> It warns against innovation ([[bid‘ah]]) to what is revealed in the Quran and the Hadiths.<ref name=g18/> It considers other religions and non-believers in Islam as wrongly guided and [[infidels]].<ref name="Juergensmeyer 2006"/><ref name=aeaa>{{cite book |author1=Aziz Esmail |author2=Abdou Filali-Ansary | title=The construction of belief | publisher=The Aga Khan University, Institute for the Study of Muslim Civilisations | location=London | year=2012 | isbn=978-0-86356-424-6 | pages=65–66}}</ref> Islam does not recognize and accept spiritual wisdom from other religions.<ref name=g18/><ref name=aeaa/><ref>{{cite journal | last=Sirriyeh | first=Elizabeth | title=Wahhabis, unbelievers and the problems of exclusivism | journal=British Society for Middle Eastern Studies | volume=16 | issue=2 | year=1989 | pages=123–132}}</ref>
Islam believes in miracles and a final judgment day ([[Qiyama]]).<ref name="Esposito 2004 121–122">{{cite book | last=Esposito | first=John | title=The Islamic world : past and present | publisher=Oxford University Press | location=New York | year=2004 | isbn=0-19-516520-9 | pages=121–122}}</ref> Islam believes that there are severe punishments in the afterlife ([[akhirah]]) for those who do not submit to God, who refuse or reject Islamic teachings, calling them [[kafir]] and [[infidels]].<ref name="Esposito 2004 121–122"/><ref>{{cite book | last=Campo | first=Juan | title=Encyclopedia of Islam | publisher=Facts On File | location=New York | year=2009 | isbn=978-0-8160-5454-1 | pages=421–422}}</ref><ref>Marilyn Robinson Waldman, The Development of the Concept of Kufr in the Quran, Vol. 88, No. 3 (Jul. - Sep., 1968), pp. 442-455</ref> Sikhism does not preach or accept this view of those who are not Sikhs.
====Apostasy==== Apostasy, that is abandonment of Islam by a Muslim and conversion to another religion or atheism, is a religious crime in Islam punishable with death.<ref name=jea>{{cite book | last=Esposito | first=John | title=The Oxford dictionary of Islam | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2003 | isbn=978-0-19-512559-7 | page=22}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last=Ali | first=Kecia | title=Islam : the key concepts | publisher=Routledge | year=2008 | isbn=978-0-415-39638-7 | pages=10–11}}</ref> According to the [[Hadith]]s, states John Esposito, leaving Islam is punishable by "beheading, crucifixion or banishment", and [[Sharia]] (Islamic legal code) traditionally has required death by the sword for an adult sane male who voluntarily leaves Islam.<ref name=jea/> However, adds Esposito, modern thinkers have argued against execution as penalty for apostasy from Islam by invoking Quranic verse 2:257.<ref name=jea/>
Sikhism allows freedom of conscience and choosing the own path.<ref name=pka>Pal Kaur, Apostasy: A sociological perspective, Sikh Review, 45(1), 1997, pp. 37-40</ref>
==== View on other religions ==== Sikhism teaches that all religious traditions are valid, leading to the same [[Waheguru]], and it rejects that any particular religion has a monopoly regarding absolute truth for all of humanity.<ref>{{cite book|first=Kristen|last=Haar|title=Sikhism|isbn=978-1417638536|year=2005|publisher=San Val|pages=43–44}}</ref>
Islam teaches that non-Islamic religious traditions have been distorted by man to suit their desires.<ref>{{cite book | last=Rippin | first=Andrew | title=The Islamic world | publisher=Routledge | location=London | year=2010 | isbn=978-0-415-60191-7 | pages=252–258}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | first=Munim| last=Sirry | title=Scriptural polemics : the Qur'an and other religions | publisher=Oxford University Press | location=Oxford New York | year=2014 | isbn=978-0-19-935936-3 | pages=43–64}}</ref>
==== Predestination ==== Islam believes in [[predestination]], or divine preordainment (''al-qadā wa l-qadar''), [[God]] has full knowledge and control over all that occurs.<ref>See: *{{cite quran|9|51|style=ref}} * D. Cohen-Mor (2001), p.4: "The idea of predestination is reinforced by the frequent mention of events 'being written' or 'being in a book' before they happen: 'Say: "Nothing will happen to us except what Allah has decreed for us…" ' " * {{cite encyclopedia | title=Fate | encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of the Qur'an Online | author=Ahmet T. Karamustafa <!--| accessdate=2007-05-02-->}}: The verb ''qadara'' literally means "to measure, to determine". Here it is used to mean that "God measures and orders his creation".</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=O84eYLVHvB0C&pg=PA591 A Dictionary of Islam]: By [[Thomas Patrick Hughes]] {{ISBN|81-206-0672-8}} Page 591</ref> According to Islamic tradition, all that has been decreed by God is written in ''al-Lawh al-Mahfūz'', the "Preserved Tablet".<ref>Farah (2003), pp.119–122; Patton (1900), p.130; Momen (1987), pp.177,178</ref>{{full citation needed|date=May 2015}}
Sikhism also believes in predestination, and what one does, speaks and hears is already pre ordained, and one has to simply follow the laid down path per God's Hukum.<ref>{{cite book | first=Gurapreet| last=Singh | title=The soul of Sikhism | year=2003 | isbn=978-81-288-0085-6 | pages=127–128}}</ref>
=== Practice ===
====Grooming and dress==== The Khalsa panth among Sikhs are guided by the [[five Ks]]. They keep their head hair long ([[Kesh (Sikhism)|kesh]]) and men wear [[turban]]s (head hair cover) Women may also wear a turban by their choice. They carry a wooden comb, wear an iron bracelet, wear a cotton underwear, and carry a [[kirpan]] (steel sword).<ref>{{cite web | title=Religion: Sikhism | website=BBC | date=1970-01-01 | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/sikhism/customs/fiveks.shtml | accessdate=2015-06-04}}</ref> Non baptized Sikh women are free to dress as they wish in Sikhism. Sex segregation is not required in public places or Sikh temples by Sikhism.<ref>{{cite book | last=Basran | first=G. S. | title=The Sikhs in Canada : migration, race, class, and gender | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2003 | isbn=978-0-19-564886-7 | pages=24–25}}</ref>
Muslim males are encouraged to grow their beards and trim the moustache.<ref name=mrg/> Men in some Muslim communities wear turban (head cap).<ref>{{cite web | last=Rubin | first=Alissa | title=Afghans Are Rattled by Rule on Searching Turbans | website=The New York Times | date=2011-10-15 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/16/world/asia/afghans-are-rattled-by-rule-on-searching-turbans.html | accessdate=2015-06-04}}</ref> Muslim men, as well as women, must dress modestly. For Muslim women, it is highly recommended to cover their hair. Muslim women are required to cover body in public,<ref>{{cite book | last=Fulkerson | first=Mary | title=The Oxford handbook of feminist theology | publisher=Oxford University Press | location=Oxford New York | year=2012 | isbn=978-0-19-927388-1 | pages=405–414}}</ref> with some Islamic scholars stating that the Islamic Hadiths require covering the face too.<ref>{{cite book | last=Hussain | first=Jamila | title=Islam : its law and society | publisher=Federation Press | location=Australia | year=2011 | isbn=978-1-86287-819-8 | pages=79–80}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title=Islam and the veil : theoretical and regional contexts | publisher=Bloomsbury Academic | location=London | year=2012 | isbn=978-1-4411-3519-3 | pages=81–85}}</ref> Islam encourages gender segregation in public, and Muslim men and women do not usually mix in public places such as mosques. These restrictions are part of '[[adab (Islam)|Adab]]'.<ref name=mrg>{{cite book | last=Martin | first=Richard | title=Encyclopedia of Islam and the Muslim world | publisher=Macmillan Reference USA Thomson/Gale | location=New York | year=2004 | isbn=978-0-02-865603-8}}</ref>
====Circumcision==== {{further information|Khitan (circumcision)|Religious views on female genital mutilation}} Sikhism does not require circumcision of either males or females, and criticizes the practice.<ref>{{cite book|author=Devinder Chahal|editor=John Peppin et al.|title=Religious Perspectives on Bioethics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lFdEAgAAQBAJ |year=2013|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-9026519673|page=213}}</ref>
In Islam, no verse in the Quran supports male or [[female genital mutilation|female circumcision]] (FGM/C).<ref>[http://www.cirp.org/library/cultural/aldeeb1/#Religious To Mutilate in the Name of Jehovah or Allah: Legitimization of Male and Female Circumcision] Sami A. ALDEEB ABU-SAHLIEH, Medicine and Law, Volume 13, Number 7-8: July 1994, pp. 575-622, Chapter 2, Quote: "The Koran mentions neither male nor female circumcision."</ref> Male circumcision is a widespread practice and considered mandatory for Muslim males according to ''[[Sunnah]]''.<ref>{{cite book|author=Erich Kolig|title=Conservative Islam: A Cultural Anthropology |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8YMu8WADEhwC&pg=PA157 |year=2012|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7391-7424-1|page=157}}, Quote: "Islam makes male circumcision mandatory, which is usually done at a relatively early age. It is not commanded by the Quran, but contained in the Sunna."</ref> Muslim scholars disagree whether any authentic ''Sunnah'' in the [[hadith]]s supports the practice of female circumcision.<ref>Ibrahim Lethome Asmani and Maryam Sheikh Abdi (2008), [http://www.unfpa.org/sites/default/files/pub-pdf/De-linking%20FGM%20from%20Islam%20final%20report.pdf De-linking Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting from Islam], Population Council, Washington DC, pages 6, 12</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=E.J. Donzel | title=Islamic desk reference | publisher=E.J. Brill | location=Leiden, Netherlands | year=1994 | isbn=90-04-09738-4 | pages=69–71}};<br>{{cite book | last=Bouhdiba | first=Abdelwahab | title=The individual and society in Islam | publisher=Unesco Pub | location=Paris | year=1998 | isbn=92-3-102742-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last=Chaim | first=Vardit | title=Islamic medical ethics in the twentieth century | publisher=E.J. Brill | location=Leiden, Netherlands | year=1993 | isbn=978-90-04-09608-0 | page=Chapter 9}}</ref> The ''[[Ijma]]'', or consensus of Muslim scholars, varies by the Islamic jurisprudence ([[fiqh]]) on whether circumcision is optional, honorable or obligatory for Muslim male and females.{{refn|group=note|name=fgmc}} Prominent Islamic scholars have both supported and opposed FGM/C for female Muslims.<ref>CM Obermeyer, "Female Genital Surgeries: The Known, the Unknown, and the Unknowable", Medical Anthropology Quarterly, 13(1), March 1999, pp. 79–106</ref><ref>[http://www.cirp.org/library/cultural/aldeeb1/#Religious To Mutilate in the Name of Jehovah or Allah: Legitimization of Male and Female Circumcision] Sami A. ALDEEB ABU-SAHLIEH, Medicine and Law, Volume 13, Number 7-8: July 1994, pp. 575-622</ref>{{refn|group=note|name=fgmc|According to Islamic scholars Ibrahim Lethome Asmani and Maryam Sheikh Abdi, "Examination of all the texts on Islamic jurisprudence (fiqh) shows that scholars have no consensus on FGM/C. For example the four schools of thought express the following views: The Hanafi view is that it is a sunnah (optional act) for both females and males; Maliki hold the view that it is wajib (obligatory) for males and sunnah (optional) for females; Shafi’i view it as wajib (obligatory) for both females and males; Hanbali have two opinions: it is wajib (obligatory) for both males and females, and it is wajib (obligatory) for males and makrumah (honourable) for females.<ref>Ibrahim Lethome Asmani and Maryam Sheikh Abdi (2008), [http://www.unfpa.org/sites/default/files/pub-pdf/De-linking%20FGM%20from%20Islam%20final%20report.pdf De-linking Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting from Islam], Population Council, Washington DC, page 13</ref>}}{{refn|group=note|According to 2016 estimates of UNICEF, at least 200 million girls and women alive today worldwide have undergone female genital mutilation/cutting.<ref>[http://data.unicef.org/topic/child-protection/female-genital-mutilation-and-cutting/ At least 200 million girls and women alive today living in 30 countries have undergone FGM/C], UNICEF (2016)</ref> The 2013 report by the UNICEF states, "in many countries, FGM/C prevalence is highest among Muslim girls and women. The practice, however, is also found among Catholic and other Christian communities."<ref>[http://data.unicef.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/FGMC_Lo_res_Final_26.pdf Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting: A statistical overview and exploration of the dynamics of change], UNICEF (2013), {{ISBN|978-92-806-4703-7}}, page 72</ref>}}
====Food==== Islam has Quranic restrictions on food, such as how the meat is prepared.<ref name="cite quran|2|173|style=nosup">{{cite quran|2|173|style=nosup}}</ref> Halal meat is required in Islam, prepared by ritual [[Animal slaughter|slaughter]] that involves cutting the [[jugular]] veins of the animal with a sharp knife. This leads to death, through bleeding, of the animal.<ref>{{cite book | last=Riaz | first=Mian | title=Halal food production | publisher=CRC Press | year=2004 | isbn=978-1-58716-029-5}}</ref> Meat from animals that die of natural causes or accident is not allowed, unless necessary.<ref name="cite quran|2|173|style=nosup"/> Beef is a religiously acceptable food to Muslims, but pork and alcohol is not.<ref>{{cite book | last=Esposito | first=John | title=What everyone needs to know about Islam | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2011 | isbn=978-0-19-979413-3 | pages=119}}</ref> Muslims fast for the month of [[Ramadan]].
Sikhs are prohibited from eating Islamic ''[[halal]]'' or Jewish ''[[kosher]]'' style meat because to them, this manner of obtaining meat involves a ritualistic component and a slow death of the animal. This is known as [[Kutha meat]].<ref name=bbcfood>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_pictures/4718511.stm|title=In pictures: Sikhs in Britain|date=27 July 2005|publisher=|via=bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref name=en2005/> The official Sikh Code of Conduct [[Sikh Rehat Maryada]] only forbids the consumption of [[Kutha meat]] and instead suggests [[Jhatka]] style of preparation.<ref name=en2005/> Charity meals distributed at a Sikh [[Gurudwara]], called a [[Langar (Sikhism)|langar]], is only [[lacto-vegetarian]].<ref name=bbcfood/><ref>{{cite book|author=Michael Angelo|title=The Sikh Diaspora: Tradition and Change in an Immigrant Community|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=te_GBQAAQBAJ |year=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-52763-0 |pages=155 }}</ref> Some groups<ref name="Takhar2005">{{cite book|last=Takhar|first=Opinderjit Kaur|title=Sikh identity: an exploration of groups among Sikhs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aeKWQzesOc4C&pg=PA51|accessdate=26 November 2010|year=2005|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7546-5202-1|page=51|chapter=2 Guru Nanak Nishkam Sewak Jatha}}</ref> of Sikhism disagree with the consumption of meat altogether.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ann Goldman|author2=Richard Hain|author3=Stephen Liben|title=Oxford Textbook of Palliative Care for Children|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f1fTsoA4wDMC&pg=PA220 |year=2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-852653-7 |pages=220 }}</ref> In practice, some Sikhs eat meat, the majority of Sikhs avoid meat. Baptized Sikhs are strict lacto-vegetarians .<ref name=en2005>{{cite book | last=Nesbitt | first=Eleanor | title=Sikhism, a very short introduction | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2005 | isbn=978-0-19-280601-7 | page=Chapter 4}}</ref>
====Jizya==== Muslim rulers in history, compelled the payment of a special tax called [[Jizya]] from [[dhimmi]], those who refuse to convert to Islam but live in a Muslim state. Dhimmis were excluded from having to pay Islamic religious tax such as [[zakat]] and excluded from observing other Islamic religious obligations.<ref>John Louis Esposito, Islam the Straight Path, Oxford University Press, 1998, pp. 33-34</ref><ref name=ame1>Anver M. Emon, Religious Pluralism and Islamic Law: Dhimmis and Others in the Empire of Law, Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|978-0199661633}}, pp. 99-109</ref> Jizya was a tool of social stratification and treasury's revenue from non-Muslims.<ref name=ame1/> Jizya was a reminder of subordination of a non-Muslim under some Muslim rulers, and created a financial and political incentive to convert to Islam.<ref name=ame1/><ref>Majid Khadduri (2010), War and Peace in the Law of Islam, Johns Hopkins University Press; pp. 162–224; {{ISBN|978-1-58477-695-6}}</ref>
Sikhism has never required a special tax for non-Sikhs.
===Holy sites=== {{wide image|Golden temple pano.jpg|760px|The Harmandir Sahib (also known as the Golden Temple).}} The [[Harmandir Sahib|Golden Temple]] (Harmandir Sahib) in Amritsar, India is not only a central religious place of the Sikhs, but also a symbol of human brotherhood and equality. The four entrances of this holy shrine from all four directions, signify that people belonging to every walk of life are equally welcome. The Golden Temple is a holy site for Sikhs and is welcome to people of any faith.<ref name="sikhs.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.sikhs.org/granth.htm|title=Sikhism Religion of the Sikh People|publisher=}}</ref>
[[File:Masjid al-Haram panorama.JPG|thumb|center|850px|<div class="center">[[Masjid al-Haram]] Mecca.</div>]] [[Mecca]] in Saudi Arabia is the central religious place in Islam.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZcMHD5WWL7AC&pg=PA26&dq=quran+revealed+medina+mecca&hl=en&ei=n9wFTvG7F8q68gPK2IHfDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Historical value of the Qur'ân and the Ḥadith] A.M. Khan</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=5ShMqiiJbNYC&pg=PA61&dq=qur'an+revealed+medina+mecca+surah&hl=en&ei=oOAFTry8H4as8gOv5-XpDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=false What Everyone Should Know About the Qur'an] Ahmed Al-Laithy</ref> Mecca is regarded as the [[holy city|holiest city]] in Islam,<ref>Nasr, Seyyed. Mecca, The Blessed, Medina, The Radiant: The Holiest Cities of Islam. Aperture. 2005</ref> and a [[pilgrimage]] to it, known as the [[Hajj]], is one of the [[pillars of Islam]]. Non-Muslims are prohibited from entering the city. Although in history, they've sometimes allowed non-Muslims to visit.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}}
;Pilgrimage Sikhs do not believe in pilgrimages; Muslims, in contrast, consider [[Hajj]] (pilgrimage to Mecca) a crucial part of the faith.
==History==
During the [[Mughal Empire]], Sikh gurus were persecuted along with other non-Muslims. The fifth Guru of Sikhs, [[Guru Arjan]] was executed by [[Jahangir]].<ref name="Singh2003">{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Prof. Kartar|title=Life Story Of Guru Nanak|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nhKMUnfLZLEC&pg=PA88|accessdate=26 November 2010|date=2003-01-01|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=978-81-7010-162-8|page=90}}</ref> There were occasional exceptions to the historical persecution. During Mughal Emperor Akbar's rule, for example, Sikhism and diverse religions were temporarily accepted. Akbar visited the third Sikh Guru, [[Guru Amar Das|Guru Amardas]] at Goindwal, ate at the [[Langar (Sikhism)|Langar]] kitchen, and offered donations for Langar.<ref name="SinghKaur1997">{{cite book|last1=Singh|first1=Inderpal|last2=Kaur|first2=Madanjit|last3=University|first3=Guru Nanak Dev|title=Guru Nanak, a global vision|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jLLXAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=26 November 2010|year=1997|publisher=Guru Nanak Dev University| asin= B0000CP9NT}}</ref><ref name="Shah1999">{{cite book|last=Shah|first=Giriraj|title=Saints, gurus and mystics of India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OAgRAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=26 November 2010|year=1999|publisher=Cosmo Publications|isbn=81-7020-856-4|page=378}}</ref>
In other periods, Sikhs were persecuted during the Islamic rule of South Asia. [[Guru Arjan]] was tortured and executed by Mughal emperor Jahangir. [[Guru Hargobind]], (sixth Guru of the Sikhs), after the martyrdom of Guru Arjan saw that it would no longer be possible to protect the [[Sikh]] community without the aid of arms.<ref name=IslamistPersecution1>V. D. Mahajan (1970). Muslim Rule In India. S. Chand, New Delhi, p.223.</ref> He built [[Akal Takhat]] the Throne of the Immortal and it is the highest political institution of the Sikhs and he also wore two swords of [http://www.sikhiwiki.org/index.php/Miri_and_Piri Miri and Piri].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sTZuAAAAMAAJ|title=Aurangzeb|first=Muni|last=Lal|date=1 December 1988|publisher=Vikas Pub. House|via=Google Books}}</ref>
[[Guru Tegh Bahadur]] (ninth Guru) was tortured and beheaded by [[Aurangzeb]] at [[Chandni Chowk]] in [[Delhi]],<ref name=IslamistPersecution2>{{cite book | last=Siṅgha | first=Kirapāla | title=Select documents on Partition of Punjab-1947 | publisher=National Book | year=2006 | isbn=978-81-7116-445-5 | page=234}}</ref> for refusing to convert to Islam and for protecting Kashmiri Hindus who were being forced to convert to Islam.<ref name=IslamistPersecution3>{{cite book|title=Later Mughals|first=William|last=Irvine|publisher=Harvard Press|isbn= 9781290917766|year=2012}}</ref><ref name=IslamistPersecution4>{{cite book |author1=Pashaura Singh |author2=Louis Fenech | title=The Oxford handbook of Sikh studies | publisher=Oxford University Press | location=Oxford, UK | year=2014 | isbn=978-0-19-969930-8 | pages=236–238}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last=Gandhi | first=Surjit | title=History of Sikh gurus retold | publisher=Atlantic Publishers | year=2007 | isbn=978-81-269-0858-5 | pages=653–691}}</ref> His fellow devotees [[Bhai Mati Das]], [[Bhai Sati Das]] and [[Bhai Dayala]] were also tortured and executed, while Guru Tegh Bahadur was forced to watch.<ref name=IslamistPersecution5>{{cite book | last=Singh | first=Prithi | title=The history of Sikh gurus | publisher=Lotus Press | year=2006 | isbn=978-81-8382-075-2 | page=124}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last=Kohli | first=Mohindar | title=Guru Tegh Bahadur : testimony of conscience | year=1992 | isbn=978-81-7201-234-2 | pages=33–61}}</ref> Tenth Guru [[Guru Gobind Singh]] formed [[Khalsa]] known as Army of [[Akal Purakh]] (Immortal) and Gave [[5 Ks]] to Khalsa. Two of the younger sons of Guru Gobind Singh aged 9 and 7 were bricked up alive by the Muslim governor [[Wazir Khan (Sirhind)|Wazir Khan]] in [[Sirhind|Sarhand]] (Punjab). When Guru Gobind Singh was in South India, he sent [[Banda Singh Bahadur]] to chastise the repressive Mughal faiy`dar of Sirhind. Banda Singh captured Sirhind and laid the foundation of Sikh empire.<ref name=pri>{{cite book | last = Singh | first = Prithi Pal | title = The history of Sikh Gurus | publisher = Lotus Press | location = | pages = 158 | isbn = 81-8382-075-1}}</ref> According to a popular myth, the Nawab of [[Malerkotla State|Malerkotla]] Sher Mohammad Khan, protested against the execution of Sahibzadas, after which Guru Gobind Singh blessed the state. This is considered as a reason by many historians due to which Malerkotla was the only city not harmed by Banda Singh Bahadur during his military campaign.<ref>{{cite book | last = Randhawa | first = Karenjot Bhangoo | title = Civil Society in Malerkotla, Punjab: Fostering Resilience Through Religion | publisher = Lexington Books | page = 62 | isbn = 978-0-739-16737-3}}</ref><ref name=oxfordforsythe>{{cite book | last = Forsythe | first = David P. | title = Encyclopedia of Human Rights, Volume 1 | publisher = Oxford University Press | page = 51 | isbn = 978-0-195-33402-9}}</ref>
The Muslims under [[Ranjit Singh]] of the [[Sikh Empire]] were mostly treated favorably and comprised the majority of the population of the empire. Ranjit Singh declared during his coronation that Muslims would be governed under [[Islamic law]] and appointed many of them in important official positions. The Muslim religious leadership and mosques continuously received state support under Sikh rule.<ref>{{cite book | last = Duggal | first = Kartar Singh | title = Maharaja Ranjit Singh, the Last to Lay Arms | publisher = Abhinav Publications | page = 55 | isbn = 978-81-7017-410-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Singh | first = Rishi | title = State Formation and the Establishment of Non-Muslim Hegemony: Post-Mughal 19th-century Punjab | publisher = SAGE Publications | page = 11 | isbn = 978-9-351-50504-4}}</ref> This was in contrast with the Muslims of [[Kashmir valley]] where Sikh rule was generally considered oppressive,<ref name=Madan>{{cite book|last=Madan|first=T. N.|authorlink=Triloki Nath Madan|chapter=Kashmir, Kashmiris, Kashmiriyat: An Introductory Essay |editor-last=Rao|editor-first=Aparna|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nIUMAQAAMAAJ|title=The Valley of Kashmir: The Making and Unmaking of a Composite Culture?|publisher=Delhi: Manohar. Pp. xviii, 758|year=2008|isbn=978-81-7304-751-0|page=15}}</ref> protected perhaps by the remoteness of Kashmir from the capital of the Sikh Empire in Lahore.<ref name=Zutshi>{{cite book|last=Zutshi|first=Chitralekha|title=Language of belonging: Islam, regional identity, and the making of Kashmir|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H7Ptp4Iod8EC|year=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press/Permanent Black|isbn=978-0-19-521939-5|pages=39–41}}</ref> The region had passed from the control of the [[Durrani Empire]] of [[Afghanistan]], and four centuries of [[Muslim]] rule under the [[Mughals]] and the [[Demographics of Afghanistan|Afghans]], to the [[Sikh Empire|Sikhs]] under Ranjit Singh in 1819.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Imperial Gazetteer of India (Volume 15); Karachi to Kotayam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3P-ctgAACAAJ|year=1908|publisher=Great Britain Commonwealth Office|isbn=978-1-154-40971-0|pages=94–95}}</ref> As the Kashmiris had suffered under the Afghans, they initially welcomed the new Sikh rulers,<ref name=SchofieldIB>{{cite book|last=Schofield|first=Victoria|title=Kashmir in conflict: India, Pakistan and the unending war|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ek00fuXVz1wC|year=2010|publisher=I. B. Tauris.|isbn=978-1-84885-105-4|pages=5–6}}</ref> however this perception later changed.<ref name=Madan/> The Sikh rulers of Kashmir enacted a number of anti-Muslim laws,<ref name=Zutshi/> which included handing out death sentences for cow slaughter,<ref name=SchofieldIB/> closing down the [[Jamia Masjid, Srinagar|Jamia Masjid]] in Srinagar, and banning the ''[[azaan]]'', the public Muslim call to prayer.<ref name=Zutshi/> Several European visitors who visited Kashmir during Sikh rule wrote of the abject poverty of the vast Muslim peasantry and of the exorbitant taxes under the Sikh rulers. High taxes, according to some contemporary accounts, had depopulated large tracts of the countryside.<ref name=SchofieldIB/> However, after a famine in 1832, the Sikhs reduced the land tax.<ref name=Zutshi/>
== Recent relations == During the [[partition of India]] in 1947, there was much bloodshed between Sikhs and Muslims, there was mass migration of people from all walks of life to leave their homes and belongings and travel by foot across the new border, on trains and on land people were killed in what was felt to be revenge attacks.<ref name=gp1>{{cite book | last=Pandey | first=Gyanendra | title=Remembering partition violence, nationalism, and history in India | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=2001 | isbn=978-0-521-00250-9 | pages=1–19, 83–88, 153–158}}</ref> Millions of Sikhs left Pakistan and moved into India, while millions of Muslims left India and moved into Pakistan.<ref name=gp1/> Malerkotla was however not affected and was viewed as a safe haven for Muslims during the partition. The popular myth associated with it is that the town was not impacted because of Guru Gobind Singh blessing it after its Nawab protested against the execution of the Guru's sons.<ref name=oxfordforsythe/>
Since [[9/11]] [[Sikhism in the United States|Sikhs in America]] have endured hate crimes, denial of employment, bullying in schools and profiling in airports.<ref>http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/268650/pinoyabroad/worldfeatures/sikhs-often-mistaken-for-muslims-call-for-better-understanding-of-their-religion</ref>
In the [[United Kingdom|UK]], there have some instances of tension between Sikhs and Muslims on allegations that some Sikhs have been [[forced to convert to Islam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00731cf|title=Asian Network Reports Special - BBC Asian Network|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/west_midlands/6738455.stm|title=Protest march over 'conversions'|date=10 June 2007|publisher=|via=bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
In 2009, the [[Taliban]] in [[Pakistan]] demanded that Sikhs in the region pay them the ''[[jizya]]'' (poll tax levied by Muslims on non-Muslim minorities).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2009/20090417/world.htm#6 |title=The Tribune, Chandigarh, India – World |publisher=Tribuneindia.com |accessdate=2010-03-09}}</ref>
In 2010 the Taliban, a terrorist group, attacked many minorities including Sikhs resulting in two beheadings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punjabnewsline.com/content/view/23629/38/ |title=Pak Sikhs seeks security, Indian citizenship |publisher=PunjabNewsline.com |date=2010-02-23 |accessdate=2010-03-09}}</ref>
In April 2016, two Muslim teens bombed a gurdwara in the German city of Essen. The two teen converted fire extinguishers into an explosive device. The devices detonated after a wedding party had left for the reception. A gurdwara priest was injured seriously, while two others were treated for minor injuries. The gurdwara building was damaged severely. One of the teens was in deradicalization program. The two denied it was religiously motivated saying “just for the kick of building fireworks!” However, before setting off the blast, the two 16-year-olds tried to break into the Sikh place of worship, North Rhine Westphalia (NRW).<ref>{{cite web|title=Sikh Temple bombing in Germany|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/sikh-temple-bombing-in-germany-was-carried-out-by-isis-sympathisers-a7007166.html|website=The Independent}}</ref>
=== Sufi Muslims and Sikhs === In South Asia alone there are over 200 million Muslims who are followers of Sufi traditions, the most notable being the [[Barelvi]] movement.<ref>{{cite|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=8Zp_5IydPGgC&pg=PA113|title=Illustrated Dictionary of the Muslim World|}}</ref> The Sikh Gurus had cordial relations with many Muslim Sufi Saints.<ref name=deol>{{cite book | last = Deol | first = Harnik | title = Religion and Nationalism in India | publisher = Routledge | year = 2000 | location = London and New York | isbn = 978-0-415-20108-7 | page = 189 }}</ref>
In December 1588, a Sufi saint of [[Lahore]], [[Mian Mir]], visited Guru Arjan Dev at the initiation ceremony before the construction of the Harmandir Sahib (Golden Temple).<ref>{{cite book | last=Jawandha | first=Nahar | title=Glimpses of Sikhism | publisher=Sanbun Publishers | year=2010 | isbn=978-93-80213-25-5 | pages=42–43}}</ref>
=== Ahmadiyya Muslims and Sikhs === [[Ahmadiyya]], a minority reform sect that arose within Islam, believe that a certain form of prophethood within Islam continues after Muhammad and consider themselves to be Muslims.<ref name=sv2008>{{cite book | last=Valentine | first=Simon | title=Islam and the Ahmadiyya jamaʻat : history, belief, practice | publisher=Columbia University Press | location=New York | year=2008 | isbn=978-0-231-70094-8 | pages=130–134}}</ref> They are, however, not recognized as Muslims by mainstream [[Sunni]] and [[Shia]] Islam, and are treated as blasphemous and persecuted.<ref name=sv2008/><ref>{{cite book | last=Gualtieri | first=Antonio | title=The Ahmadis community, gender, and politics in a Muslim society | publisher=McGill-Queen's University Press | location=Montreal, Que | year=2004 | isbn=978-0-7735-2738-6|page=135}}</ref> Since the 18th century, Sufis and ancestors of Mirza Ghulam Ahmad – the founder of the Ahmadiyya Movement – had cordial relations with Sikhs, and they fought with Sikhs to resist the persecution by Sunni-based Mughal rule in northwest region of South Asia.<ref name=khan2015p22>{{cite book | last=Khan | first=Adil | title=From Sufism to Ahmadiyya a Muslim minority movement in South Asia | publisher=Indiana University Press | location=Bloomington | year=2015 | isbn=978-0-253-01523-5 | pages=22–27}}</ref> However, as [[Ranjit Singh]] established the Sikh Empire, there were conflicts between the Sikhs and the [[Jagir]] of Ahmad's father.<ref name= khan2015p22/>
==See also== * [[Battle of Chamkaur]] * [[Conversion of non-Muslim places of worship into mosques]] * [[Divisions of the world in Islam]] * [[Islam and other religions]] * [[Mughal Empire]] * [[Hinduism and Sikhism]] * [[Jainism and Sikhism]] * [[Ganga Sagar (urn)]]

{{see also|Spread of Islam in Southeast Asia|Spread of Islam in Indonesia|Muslim Southeast Asia}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2015}}{{refimprove|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}}[[Islam]] is the most widely practiced religion in [[Southeast Asia]], numbering approximately 240 million adherents which translate to about 40% of the entire population, with majorities in [[Brunei]], [[Indonesia]] and [[Malaysia]] as well [[Pattani (region)|Pattani]] in Thailand and [[Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao|parts of Mindanao]] in the [[Philippines]] respectively.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yusuf|first=Imtiyaz|year=|title=The Middle East and Muslim Southeast Asia: Implications of the Arab Spring|url=http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/Public/focus/essay1009_southeast_asia.html|journal=Oxford Islamic Studies|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Significant minorities are located in the other Southeast Asian states. Most Muslims in Southeast Asia are [[Sunni]] and follow the [[Shafi`i]] school of [[fiqh]], or religious law.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/Public/focus/essay1009_southeast_asia.html|title=The Middle East and Muslim Southeast Asia: Implications of the Arab Spring|last=Yusuf|first=Imtiyaz|date=|website=Oxford Islamic Studies Online|publisher=Oxford University Press|access-date=14 September 2016}}</ref> It is the official religion in Malaysia and Brunei while it is one of the six official faiths in Indonesia.
'''Islam in Southeast Asia''' is heterogeneous and is manifested in many different ways. Some places in Southeast Asia, Islam is adapted to coexist with already existent local traditions.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|title=Southeast Asia and Islam|journal=The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science|volume= 588, Islam: Enduring Myths and Changing Realities (Jul., 2003), pp. 149-170}}</ref> [[Mysticism]] is a defining characteristic of Islam in Southeast Asia, with a large following of [[Sufi]]sm. Mystic forms of Islam fit in well with already established traditions.<ref name=":02"/> The adaptation of Islam to local traditions is seen as a positive thing by Muslims in Southeast Asia.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Voices of Islam in Southeast Asia : a contemporary sourcebook|last=Fealy|first=Greg|last2=Hooker|first2=Virginia|publisher=ISEAS Publications|year=2006|isbn=|location=Singapore|pages=411|quote=|via=}}</ref> Islam is part of everyday life in Southeast Asia and is not separated from "non-religious realms".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Islam in South-East Asia|last=Hooker|first=M.B.|publisher=Leiden ; New York : E.J. Brill|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> Southeast Asia contains the highest number of Muslims in the world, easily surpassing the Middle East and North Africa.<ref name=":02"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2012/12/18/global-religious-landscape-muslim/|title=Muslims|date=2012-12-18|website=Pew Research Center's Religion & Public Life Project|access-date=2016-10-13}}</ref> Islam in Southeast Asia is neglected in Western study of Islam which centers around the Middle East.<ref name=":22">{{Cite book|title=Islam|last=Denny|first=Fredrick Mathewson|publisher=Harper & Row|year=1987|isbn=|location=San Francisco|pages=6|quote=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":13">{{Cite book|title=Indonesia: Peoples and History|last=Taylor|first=Jean Gelman Taylor|publisher=Yale|year=2003|isbn=|location=New Haven|pages=66|quote=|via=}}</ref> Southeast Asia is a world region made up of nations sharing little more than geographical proximity with one another. What it means to be Southeast Asian is vague and can mean very different things to the people of the arbitrarily assigned world region that comprises Brunei, Cambodia, East Timor, Indonesia, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam. The heterogeneous nature of Southeast Asia combined with the widely varying practices and meanings of Islam means Islam in Southeast Asia has a multitude of variations in practice and belief. Islam in Southeast Asia has been adapted to varying local norms across Southeast Asia. The [[Abangan]] are the dominant group of Muslims in Indonesia.<ref name=":22"/> The practices of the Abangan are heavily influenced by mysticism and embody a unique form of Islamic practice that incorporates rituals inherited from their pre Islamic ancestors.<ref name=":22"/>
{| border=1 align=right cellpadding=4 cellspacing=0 width=250 style="margin: 0 0 1em 1em; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Early Islam converts!! year |- | [[Sultan Mudzafar Shah I|Phra Ong Mahawangsa]] of [[Kedah Kingdom]] || 1160 - 1179 |- | [[Malik ul Salih|King Merah Silu]] of [[Pasai]] || 1267 - 12?? |- | [[Megat Iskandar Shah (Sultan of Malacca)|Megat Iskandar Shah]] of [[Sultan of Malacca|Malacca]]|| 1414 - 1424 |- | Kertawijaya (Bhre Tumapel) of [[Majapahit]] || 1447 - 1451 |}
==History==
According to the Islamic Council of Victoria, historians argue that Arab merchants dominated trade in Southeast Asia in the early ninth century. There existed a colony of foreign Muslims on the west coast of Sumatra by 674 CE; other Muslim settlements began to appear after 878 CE when Islam increasingly took root among the people. However, little remains from these early communities, and the religion did not spread to significant parts of the population until the 12th century.
[[File:Food jar (gadur), Mindanao, Maranao, brass with silver inlay, Honolulu Academy of Arts.JPG|thumb|A Muslim "Food jar" from the [[Philippines]], also known as ''gadur'', well known for its [[brass]] with [[silver]] inlay.]]
Islam came to the Southeast Asia, first by the way of Muslim traders along the main trade-route between [[Western Asia]] and the [[Far East]], then was further spread by [[Tariqah|Sufi orders]] and finally consolidated by the expansion of the territories of converted rulers and their communities.<ref name="Camb">P. M. ( Peter Malcolm) Holt, Bernard Lewis, ''"The Cambridge History of Islam"'', Cambridge University Press, pr 21, 1977, {{ISBN|0-521-29137-2}} pg.123-125</ref> The first communities arose in [[Aceh]] in Northern [[Sumatra]]. [[Malacca]] was a stronghold of Islam as well, from where it was propagated along the trade routes in the region.<ref name="Camb"/> There is no clear indication of when Islam first came to the region, the first Muslim gravestone markings date to 1082.<ref name="colin">Colin Brown, ''A Short History of Indonesia"'', Allen & Unwin, July 1, 2003 {{ISBN|1-86508-838-2}} pg.31-33</ref>
When [[Marco Polo]] visited the area in 1292 he noted that the urban port state of [[Peureulak|Perlak]] was Muslim,<ref name="colin"/> Chinese sources record the presence of a Muslim delegation to the emperor from the [[Pasai|Kingdom of Samudra (Pasai)]] in 1282,<ref name="Camb"/> other accounts provide instances of Muslim communities present in the [[Melayu Kingdom]] for the same time period while others record the presence of Muslim Chinese traders from provinces such as [[Fujian]].<ref name="colin"/> The spread of Islam generally followed the trade routes east through the primarily [[Buddhist]] region and a half century later in the [[Malacca]]'s we see the first dynasty arise in the form of the [[Sultanate of Malacca]] at the far end of the Archipelago form by the conversion of one [[Parameswara (sultan)|Parameswara Dewa Shah]] into a Muslim and the adoption of the name Muhammad Iskandar Shah after his marriage to a daughter of the ruler of Pasai.<ref name="Camb"/><ref name="colin"/> In 1380, Sufi orders carried Islam from here on to [[Mindanao]].<ref name="Nazeer">Nazeer Ahmed, ''"Islam in Global History: From the Death of Prophet Muhammed to the First World War"'', Xlibris Corporation, December 1, 2000, {{ISBN|0-7388-5962-1}} pg. 394-396</ref>{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}
Another driving force for the change of the ruling class in the region was the concept among the increasing Muslim communities of the region when ruling dynasties to attempt to forge such ties of kinship by marriage.<ref name="Nazeer"/> By the time the [[Colonialism|colonial]] powers and their [[missionaries]] arrived in the 17th century the region up to [[New Guinea]] was overwhelmingly Muslim with [[animist]] minorities.<ref name="colin"/>
The first written sources of Islam in Southeast Asia in 916 AD from a merchant describing his experience in 1?851 on the Island of Sumatra.<ref name=":13"/> Over time a series of Muslim port villages emerged on the scarcely populated coast.<ref name=":13"/> Islamic teachers from these port villages ventured to the interior of Sumatra.<ref name=":13"/> Over time these ports attracted Muslims from India, China, and the Arabian peninsula.<ref name=":13"/> These communities surpassed their utilitarian functions for trade and were integrated into the global network of Islam.<ref name=":13"/> Islam was popular in Southeast Asia because it, unlike previous belief systems could be used to validate a ruler's power through the divine. Islam spread throughout the Indonesian archipelago slowly and with force.<ref name=":02"/>
In the 12th century, the [[India]]n [[Chola]] navy crossed the ocean and attacked the [[Srivijaya]] kingdom of Sangrama Vijayatunga Varman in Kadaram ([[Kedah Kingdom|Kedah]]). The capital of the powerful maritime kingdom was sacked and the king was taken captive. Along with Kadaram, Pannai in present-day [[Sumatra]] and Malaiyur and the Malayan peninsula were attacked. Soon after, the King of Kedah Phra Ong Mahawangsa became the first ruler to abandon the traditional [[Hindu]] faith and converted to [[Islam]] with the [[Sultanate of Kedah]] established in year 1136. [[Samudera Pasai]] converted to Islam in the year 1267. The King of Malacca [[Parameswara (sultan)|Parameswara]] married the princess of Pasai, and their son became the first sultan of Malacca. Soon Malacca became the centre of Islamic study and maritime trade; other rulers followed suit.
By the end of the 15th century, several areas of northern Sumatra, including what is now Java, were governed by Muslim rulers.<ref name=":13"/> It wasn’t until 1641 that the first Sultan took their title in what is now Java.<ref name=":13" /> Islam initially arrived on the coast of Sumatra, and spread down and around the coast to the Malacca strait and jumped across the straight to the Malay Peninsula.<ref name=":22"/>
In 1511, the Portuguese took over Malacca, but various other Muslim states began to grow in size and economic and political prominence. For example, Aceh dominated the region, both politically and economically, in the early seventeenth century. Through familial and trade relationships in these Muslim states, non-Islam states were slowly exposed to the faith. As it spread, Islam encountered pre-existing spiritual beliefs<ref name=":1">[http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?tabID=T003&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchId=R1&searchType=BasicSearchForm&currentPosition=4&userGroupName=lacc_main&inPS=true&sort=RELEVANCE&contentSegment=&prodId=GVRL.LACCMAIN&contentSet=GALE%7CCX3424501558&&docId=GALE%7CCX3424501558&docType=GALE "Gale - Enter Product Login"]. ''go.galegroup.com''. Retrieved 2016-11-07.</ref>—including Buddhism and Hinduism<ref name=":2">[http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780195125580.001.0001/acref-9780195125580-e-2247?rskey=H8F68x&result=1 "Southeast Asia, Islam in - Oxford Reference"]. [[Digital object identifier|doi]]:[[doi:10.1093/acref/9780195125580.001.0001/acref-9780195125580-e-2247|10.1093/acref/9780195125580.001.0001/acref-9780195125580-e-2247]].</ref>—which continued to be practiced alongside Islam or were incorporated into Islam. Indeed, the faith introduced by some of the religious merchants was Sufism, a mystical version of Islam that is rejected by more conservative Muslims.<ref name=":3">Houissa, Ali. [http://guides.library.cornell.edu/IslamSoutheastAsia "LibGuides: Islam in Southeast Asia: Home"]. ''guides.library.cornell.edu''. Retrieved 2016-10-24.</ref> Islamic law was also formally practiced in most areas that had encountered Islam, affecting cultural practices.<ref name=":1" /> [[File:Knocking Out the Moros. DA Poster 21-48.jpg|thumb|[[Moro Rebellion]] against the [[United States military]] during the [[Philippine-American War]] in 1913]]
There are several theories to the [[Islamization]] process in Southeast Asia. The first theory is trade. The expansion of trade among [[West Asia]], [[India]] and Southeast Asia helped the spread of the religion as Muslim traders brought Islam to the region. [[Gujarati Muslims]] played a pivotal role in establishing [[Islam]] in [[Southeast Asia]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Gujarat helped establish Islam in SE Asia|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/ampnbspGujarat-helped-establish-Islam-in-SE-Asia/articleshow/11262585.cms|publisher=[[The Times of India]]|last=Prabhune|first=Tushar|location=[[Ahmedabad]]|date=December 27, 2011}}</ref> The second theory is the role of missionaries or [[Sufi]]s. The Sufi missionaries played a significant role in spreading the faith by syncretising Islamic ideas with existing local beliefs and religious notions. Finally, the ruling classes embraced Islam which further aided the permeation of the religion throughout the region. The ruler of the region's most important port, [[Malacca Sultanate]], embraced Islam in the 15th century, heralding a period of accelerated conversion of Islam throughout the region as the religion provided a unifying force among the ruling and trading classes near mister man. The word ''daulat'' refers to the legitimacy of a ruler, through the power of God, and suggests the strong relationship between rule, legitimacy, and the spread of Islam.<ref name=":4">[http://islamtoday.berkeley.edu/Islam_SoutheastAsia "Islam in Southeast Asia | Islam, Youth & New Media"]. ''islamtoday.berkeley.edu''. Retrieved 2016-11-05.</ref>
The spread of Islam to Southeast Asia also depended largely on the translation and availability of religious texts. This was largely through Malay, a language that transected class.<ref name=":2" /> There are also a number of works in Javanese, particularly related to Javanese-Islamic mysticism.<ref name=":5">Houben, Vincent (2003). "Southeast Asia and Islam". ''The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science''. '''588''': 149–170.</ref> Some of the most significant Malay authors that helped in this translation are Hamzah Fansuri, Shams al-Din, and 'Abd al-Ra-uf.<ref name=":1" />
==Contemporary Islam in Southeast Asia== Islam in Southeast Asia is multi-faceted and multi-layered. Different interpretations of the faith have resulted in a variety of groups. In Indonesia, there is the [[Nahdlatul Ulama]], which preaches closely to the Shafi`i school of legal accretion, and the [[Muhammadiyah]], whose outlook is a blend of modernist ideals with Islamic thoughts. Along with these two major groups, other Islamic groups also played an important role in Indonesian society, politics and economy, with their followers forming Islamic civil groups and political parties. Muslims in Southeast Asia also come from a variety of ethnic groups and backgrounds and speak a number of different languages, including Thai, Burmese, Malay, Marano, Tausug, Bahasa Indonesia, Javanese, and Chinese.<ref name=":3" /> Through travel to Arab countries—for the Hajj-pilgrimage or religious study—Muslims in Southeast Asia have also undertaken the translation of Islamic texts into local languages. Daily practices also vary among countries and different regions within each country. Many of these differences relate to government policies and also to whether Muslims make up the majority or minority of the country's population.<ref name=":5" />
[[File:Istiqlal Mosque Eid ul Fitr Jamaah 4.JPG|right|thumb|[[Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta]]]] [[File:นายกรัฐมนตรี มอบบ้านตามโครงการแก้ไขปัญหาความเดือดร้อนท - Flickr - Abhisit Vejjajiva (10).jpg|thumb|[[Thai Malays]]]] Despite these differences, there are still common traditions practiced among many Muslims in Southeast Asia. For example, the [[Five Pillars of Islam|five duties of Islam]] (Faith, Prayer, Charity, Fasting, Pilgrimage) form a foundation for many individuals' faith. Likewise, there are other shared traditions, such as prayer before meals.<ref>[http://asiasociety.org/education/islam-southeast-asia "Islam in Southeast Asia"]. ''Asia Society''. Retrieved 2016-10-24.</ref>
Since the late 1970s, an Islamic resurgence is taking place in the region. [[Dakwah]] movements mushroomed throughout Southeast Asia. These movements, in general, aim to create a strong Islamic identity among the Muslims and are understood as a response to changes in society and values. These movements have been referred to as "revivalism," "revitalization," "resurgence," "renewal," and "Islamization."<ref name=":5" /> As a result, Islam began to assume a larger role in public life, underlined by the increased donning of [[Hijab|headscarves]] among Muslim women, for one example. Economic growth resulted in modest affluence which has translated into more religious investments like the [[Haj]]<nowiki/>j and [[Islamic]] literature. The Malaysian government promotes Islam through its Islamization policies covering society, economics and education and, most recently, [[Islam Hadhari]]. Some of these movements have reflected a perceived tension between modernity and tradition, and they reflect movements taking place at the same time in other regions, like the Middle East. For example, Southeast Asian scholars who traveled to the Middle East during the early 1900s brought back ideas from the Modernist movement. In Indonesia, there are two large Muslim organizations. One, [[Muhammadiyah]], is associated with this Modernist movement while the other, [[Nahdlatul Ulama]], is a more traditional organization meant to oppose the values of Modernism.<ref name=":4" />
Islam has intersected with other religious practices in Southeast Asia in many different ways. For example, ''jinn'', which indicates Islamic spiritual beings, has come to include Javanese spirits, as well. In countries such as Indonesia, in particular, animist traditions (as well as the traditions of other faiths, like Hindu and Buddhism) have become integral to the practice of Islam. Sufism has also shaped Islam in many Southeast Asian countries.<ref name=":4" />
Pilgrimage to the Holy Cities of Mecca and Medina is one of the Five Pillars of Islam.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/islam/practices/fivepillars.shtml|title=BBC - Religions - Islam: Five Pillars of Islam|access-date=2016-11-22}}</ref> The Hajj was made easier by the advent of the steamship in the 19th century.<ref name=":05">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/Public/focus/essay1009_southeast_asia.html|title=Focus On... - Oxford Islamic Studies Online|website=www.oxfordislamicstudies.com|access-date=2016-11-22}}</ref> As the Hajj became more popular throughout Southeast Asia, Arabic and the Arabian brand of Islam were integrated further into the lives of Muslims in Southeast Asia.<ref name=":05" /> In accordance with the body of scholarly work on Islam in the Southeast Asia, the Hajj from Southeast garnered little to no attention.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.international.ucla.edu/asia/article/24195|title=Hajj Histories: Stories from Southeast Asian Pilgrims|website=www.international.ucla.edu|access-date=2016-11-22}}</ref>
In today's modern age, Muslims interact with global technology, consumerism, and ideas in a variety of ways while practicing their faith. For some, this has resulted in an increase in religiosity and the observation of traditions such as Islamic devotional practices and fasting during Ramadan. As another example, Muslims in Southeast Asia have performed pilgrimages to the Mecca since the 17th century and continue to do so.<ref name=":6">''Voices of Islam in Southeast Asia: A Contemporary Sourcebook''. Singapore: Institute of Southeast Asian Studies Publications. 2006. {{ISBN|9812303685}}.</ref>
In Southeast Asia, Islam also influences other aspects of life, and there is a close relationship among religion, nation, and ethnicity.<ref name=":5" /> For example, there are an increasing number of private Islamic schools, which often combine Islamic religion, culture, and life. Likewise, medicine in Southeast Asia draws on a number of traditions, often combining animism, tibbun (which contains pre-Islamic elements), and hikmah (which is based upon a lineage of Muslim scholars and influenced modern biomedical practice).<ref name=":6" /> Islamic banks are also founded on Islamic principles and, for example, do not charge interest.
The division of countries during colonialism divide some ethnic and religious groups, leading to some minority Muslim populations that live at the edge of countries. Various organizations, like the Muslim World League, have advocated for the rights of these minority populations.<ref name=":5" /> There is a [[persecution of Muslims in Myanmar|history]] in some countries of [[persecution]] of Muslims, including the ongoing [[ethnic cleansing]] of the [[Rohingya persecution in Myanmar (2016–present)|Rohingya in Myanmar]].<ref name="BBC 2017">{{cite news|title=UN condemns 'devastating' Rohingya abuse in Myanmar|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-38858655|accessdate=4 February 2017|publisher=BBC News|date=3 February 2017}}</ref>
Finally, the war on terrorism, particularly since 9/11, has influenced contemporary Islam in Southeast Asia. Many governments in the region have joined antiterrorist coalitions or signed antiterrorist pacts. In some countries, such as the Philippines, the U.S. has sent troops to combat specific terrorist groups associated with Islamic extremism.<ref name=":5" />

{{short description|A period in Islamic history between the 8th and 14th centuries}} [[File:Maqamat hariri.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|Scholars at an Abbasid library, from the [[Maqama]]t of [[Al-Hariri of Basra|al-Hariri]] by [[Yahya ibn Mahmud al-Wasiti]], [[Baghdad]], 1237 AD]] The '''Islamic Golden Age''' is the era in the [[history of Islam]], traditionally dated from the 8th century to the 14th century, during which much of the historically [[Islamic world]] was ruled by various [[caliphate]]s, and [[science in the medieval Islamic world|science]], economic development and cultural works flourished.<ref name=Saliba>[[George Saliba]] (1994), ''A History of Arabic Astronomy: Planetary Theories During the Golden Age of Islam'', pp. 245, 250, 256–7. [[New York University Press]], {{ISBN|0-8147-8023-7}}.</ref><ref name=King>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1086/353360 | last1 = King | first1 = David A. | year = 1983 | title = The Astronomy of the Mamluks | url = | journal = Isis | volume = 74 | issue = 4| pages = 531–555 | ref = harv }}</ref><ref name=Hassan-Decline/> This period is traditionally understood to have begun during the reign of the [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid]] caliph [[Harun al-Rashid]] (786 to 809) with the inauguration of the [[House of Wisdom]] in [[Baghdad]], where scholars from various parts of the world with different cultural backgrounds were mandated to gather and translate all of the world's classical knowledge into the [[Arabic language]].<ref>Medieval India, NCERT, {{ISBN|81-7450-395-1}}</ref><ref name="Vartan">Vartan Gregorian, "Islam: A Mosaic, Not a Monolith", Brookings Institution Press, 2003, pg 26–38 {{ISBN|0-8157-3283-X}}</ref> This period is traditionally said to have ended with the collapse of the Abbasid caliphate due to [[Mongol invasions and conquests|Mongol invasions]] and the [[Siege of Baghdad (1258)|Siege of Baghdad]] in 1258 AD.<ref name="Tahir Abbas">{{cite book|title=Islamic Radicalism and Multicultural Politics |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=JdC90uc8PfQC |page=9 }} |accessdate=26 August 2012|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-136-95960-8|page=9|date=2011-03-01}}</ref> A few contemporary scholars place the end of the Islamic Golden Age as late as the end of 15th to 16th centuries.<ref name=Saliba/><ref name=King/><ref name=Hassan-Decline/>
==History of the concepts== [[File:Map of expansion of Caliphate.svg|thumb|Expansion of the [[Caliphate]]s, 622–750. {{legend|#a1584e|Expansion under [[Muhammad]], 622–632}} {{legend|#ef9070|Expansion during the [[Rashidun Caliphate]], 632–661}} {{legend|#fad07d|Expansion during the [[Umayyad Caliphate]], 661–750}}]] The metaphor of a [[Golden age (metaphor)|golden age]] began to be applied in 19th-century literature about Islamic history, in the context of the western aesthetic fashion known as [[Orientalism]]. The author of a ''Handbook for Travelers in Syria and Palestine'' in 1868 observed that the most beautiful mosques of Damascus were "like Mohammedanism itself, now rapidly decaying" and relics of "the golden age of Islam".<ref>Josias Leslie Porter, ''A Handbook for Travelers in Syria and Palestine'', 1868, [{{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=zdfotKk6OtsC |page=49 }} p. 49].</ref>
There is no unambiguous definition of the term, and depending on whether it is used with a focus on cultural or on military achievement, it may be taken to refer to rather disparate time spans. Thus, one author would have it extend to the duration of the caliphate, or to "six and a half centuries",<ref>"For six centuries and a half, through the golden age of Islam, lasted this Caliphate, till extinguished by the Osmanli sultans and in the death of the last of the blood of the house of Mahomet. The true Caliphate ended with the fall of Bagdad". ''New Outlook'', Volume 45, 1892, p. 370.</ref> while another would have it end after only a few decades of Rashidun conquests, with the death of [[Umar]] and the [[First Fitna]].<ref>"the golden age of Islam, as Mr. Gilman points out, ended with Omar, the second of the Kalifs." ''The Literary World'', Volume 36, 1887, p. 308.</ref>
During the early 20th century, the term was used only occasionally, and often referred to the early military successes of the [[Rashidun Caliphs|Rashidun caliphs]]. It was only in the second half of the 20th century that the term came to be used with any frequency, now mostly referring to the cultural flourishing of science and mathematics under the caliphates during the 9th to 11th centuries (between the establishment of organised scholarship in the [[House of Wisdom]] and the beginning of the [[crusades]]),<ref>"The Ninth, Tenth and Eleventh centuries were the golden age of Islam" ''LIFE'' magazine, 9 May 1955, [{{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=llYEAAAAMBAJ |page=74 }} p.74].</ref> but often extended to include part of the late 8th or the 12th to early 13th centuries.<ref>so Linda S. George, ''The Golden Age of Islam'', 1998: "from the last years of the eighth century to the thirteenth century."</ref> Definitions may still vary considerably. Equating the end of the golden age with the end of the caliphates is a convenient cut-off point based on a historical landmark, but it can be argued that Islamic culture had entered a gradual decline much earlier; thus, Khan (2003) identifies the proper golden age as being the two centuries between 750–950, arguing that the beginning loss of territories under Harun al-Rashid worsened after the death of [[al-Ma'mun]] in 833, and that the [[crusades]] in the 12th century resulted in a weakening of the [[Ayyubid dynasty|Islamic empire]] from which it never recovered.<ref>Arshad Khan, ''Islam, Muslims, and America: Understanding the Basis of Their Conflict'', 2003, [{{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=FbnnJxar3aMC |page=19 }} p. 19].</ref>
==Causes==
===Religious influence=== {{Main|Islamic attitudes towards science}} The various [[Quran]]ic injunctions and [[prophetic traditions|Hadith]], which place values on education and emphasize the importance of acquiring knowledge, played a vital role in influencing the Muslims of this age in their search for knowledge and the development of the body of science.<ref name=Hans45>{{cite book |editor1-first=Hans |editor1-last=Groth|title=Population Dynamics in Muslim Countries: Assembling the Jigsaw |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Bpq9Mg-l5jMC&pg=PA45 |accessdate= |year=2012 |publisher=Springer Science & Business Media |location= |isbn=9783642278815 |page=45}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |editor1-first=Hamid Naseem |editor1-last=Rafiabadi |title=Challenges to Religions and Islam: A Study of Muslim Movements, Personalities, Issues and Trends, Part 1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KnH_YuN2ruUC&pg=PA1141 |accessdate= |year=2007 |publisher=Sarup & Sons |location= |isbn=9788176257329 |page=1141}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Salam |first=Abdus |title=Renaissance of Sciences in Islamic Countries |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KfoQmi4o4zcC&pg=PA9 |accessdate= |publisher= |location= |isbn= 9789971509460|page=9|year=1994 }}</ref>
===Government sponsorship=== The [[Islamic Empire]] heavily patronized scholars. The money spent on the [[Translation Movement]] for some translations is estimated to be equivalent to about twice the annual research budget of the United Kingdom’s [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|Medical Research Council]].<ref name=bbc2>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01k2bv8|title=In Our Time - Al-Kindi, James Montgomery|publisher=bbcnews.com|accessdate=May 18, 2013|date=28 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114060124/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01k2bv8#|archive-date=2014-01-14|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> The best scholars and notable translators, such as [[Hunayn ibn Ishaq]], had salaries that are estimated to be the equivalent of professional athletes today.<ref name=bbc2/> The [[House of Wisdom]] was a [[library]] established in [[Abbasid]]-era [[Baghdad]], [[Iraq]] by Caliph [[al-Mansur]].<ref>{{cite book |author1-first=Sonja |author1-last=Brentjes |author2=Robert G. Morrison |chapter=The Sciences in Islamic societies |title=The New Cambridge History of Islam |volume=4 |place=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |date=2010 |pages=569}}</ref>
===Earlier cultural influence=== {{Main|Greek contributions to Islamic world|Indian influence on Islamic science|Christian influences in Islam|Chinese influences on Islamic pottery}} During this period, the Muslims showed a strong interest in assimilating the scientific knowledge of the civilizations that had been conquered. Many classic works of antiquity that might otherwise have been lost were translated from [[Ancient Greece|Greek]], [[Persian Empire|Persian]], [[History of India|Indian]], [[History of China|Chinese]], [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]], and [[Phoenicia]]n civilizations into Arabic and Persian, and later in turn translated into Turkish, Hebrew, and Latin.<ref name="Vartan"/>
[[Christians]], especially the adherents of the [[Church of the East]] ([[Nestorian]]s), contributed to Islamic civilization during the reign of the [[Ummayads]] and the [[Abbasids]] by translating works of [[Greek philosophers]] and [[ancient science]] to [[Syriac Language|Syriac]] and afterwards to [[Arabic Language|Arabic]].<ref>Hill, Donald. ''Islamic Science and Engineering''. 1993. Edinburgh Univ. Press. {{ISBN|0-7486-0455-3}}, p.4</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Nestorians|title=Nestorian - Christian sect|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028023759/https://www.britannica.com/topic/Nestorians#|archive-date=2016-10-28|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> They also excelled in many fields, in particular [[philosophy]], [[science]] (such as [[Hunayn ibn Ishaq]],<ref name="Rashed">{{cite book|last=Rashed|first=Roshdi|title=Classical Mathematics from Al-Khwarizmi to Descartes|url=https://books.google.com/?id=F_VTBAAAQBAJ|year=2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-83388-2|page=33}}</ref><ref name="Britannica">{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/biography/Hunayn-ibn-Ishaq|title=Hunayn ibn Ishaq - Arab scholar|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160531073842/http://www.britannica.com/biography/Hunayn-ibn-Ishaq#|archive-date=2016-05-31|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> [[Thābit ibn Qurra|Thabit Ibn Qurra]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.larouchepub.com/other/2013/4041baghdad_melting_pot.html|title=Baghdad 767-1258 A.D.:Melting Pot for a Universal Renaissance|last=Hussein|first=Askary|date=|website=Executive Intelligence Review.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170824153753/http://www.larouchepub.com/other/2013/4041baghdad_melting_pot.html#|archive-date=2017-08-24|dead-url=no|access-date=|df=}}</ref> [[Yusuf Al-Khuri]],<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FbpACwAAQBAJ&pg=PT113&dq=yusuf+al+khuri+al+qass#v=onepage&q=yusuf%20al%20khuri%20al%20qass&f=false|title=How Greek Science Passed On To The Arabs|journal=Nature|volume=163|issue=4150|pages=748|last=O'Leary|first=Delacy|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|bibcode=1949Natur.163Q.748T|year=1949|doi=10.1038/163748c0|isbn=9781317847489}}</ref> [[Ibn Na'ima al-Himsi|Al Himsi]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.levity.com/alchemy/islam14.html|title=History of Islamic Science|last=Sarton|first=George|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812023045/http://www.levity.com/alchemy/islam14.html#|archive-date=2016-08-12|dead-url=no|access-date=|df=}}</ref> [[Qusta ibn Luqa]],<ref>Nancy G.
